definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.24

example: A functional user requirement "Maintain Customers" consists of the following BFCs: "Add a new customer", "Report Customer Purchases", and "Change Customer Details". A collection of logically related business data is maintained by the software as "Customer Details".

definitions.text: defined category of Base Functional Component
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 2.2

definitions.text: measure defined in terms of an attribute and the method for quantifying it

definitions.text: activity that, when consistently performed, contributes to achieving a specific process purpose

definitions.text: approved International Standard or Telecommunication Standardization Sector of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU-T) Recommendation

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.3

name: baseline

note: Some baselines are project deliverables, while others provide the basis for further work. A baseline, together with all approved changes to the baseline, represents the current approved configuration. The term is thus used to refer to a particular version of a software configuration item that has been agreed on, e.g., as a stable base for further development or to mark a specific project milestone. In either case, any new baseline is agreed through the project's agreed change control procedures.

It can denote unbundling of arrow meaning, i.e., the separation of object types from an object type set. Also refers to an arrow segment into which a root arrow segment has been divided.

name: breakpoint

definitions.text: point in a computer program at which execution can be suspended to permit manual or automated monitoring of program performance or results

note: Types include code breakpoint, data breakpoint, dynamic breakpoint, epilog breakpoint, programmable breakpoint, prolog breakpoint, static breakpoint. A breakpoint is said to be set when both a point in the program and an event that will cause suspension of execution at that point are defined; it is said to be initiated when program execution is suspended.

note: A bundle can be referred to as a suite, if the products are closely related and typically integrated (such as an office suite containing a spreadsheet, word processor, presentation and other related items). Bundles can also refer to software titles that are less closely related such as a game, a virus scanner and a utility bundled together with a new computer, or to groups of entitlements, such as multiple entitlements for a backup software product.

definitions.text: an indicator of the work completed and an estimate of remaining work to be completed or remaining effort needed to complete a product development iteration cycle. Work is measured as all work done to deliver story points, stories, features, functions, function points, user stories, use cases, or requirements during a product development iteration.

name: business information management

definitions.text: domain responsible for all of the tasks and activities that are aimed at supporting the end users in the use of the application and at acting as the customer of the IT organizations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.8

note: Business information management represents the business as the customer organization or client of the application management and IT infrastructure management organizations in maintaining the functionality of the information provisioning and the information systems. It is the demand side of the information provisioning. An information system can have non-automated elements such as forms and user guides. Those elements are usually maintained by the business information management organization.

definitions.text: strategy designed by senior management to ensure an organization's continued existence and enhance its profitability, market share, and other factors influencing the organization's success
partially ordered set of enterprise activities that can be executed to achieve some desired end-result in pursuit of a given objective of an organization

a concept that is unique to each organization and includes tangible and intangible elements. Through the effective use of project, program, and portfolio management disciplines, organizations will possess the ability to employ reliable, established processes to meet enterprise objectives and obtain greater business value from their investments.
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: pertaining to a system or component that is operational, in service, and in use

name: busy time

definitions.text: in computer performance engineering, the period of time during which a system or component is operational, in service, and in use

note: operational, in service, and in use

definitions.text: acquirer of products, services, or results for an organization
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: group of adjacent binary digits operated upon as a unit and usually shorter than a computer word (frequently connotes a group of eight bits)
element of computer storage that can hold a group of bits as in (1)
string that consists of a number of bits, treated as a unit, and usually representing a character or a part of a character
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: command, control, communications, computer, and intelligence
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: temporary storage in computer memory, to improve operations by having frequently used data readily available for retrieval2. RAM with very high operating speed used for data storage within a processor
Computer Aided Design
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-1:1998 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference model: Overview

definitions.text: frequency of performing a periodic activity, such as incremental product release
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: critical application item
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.1:2014 IEEE Standard for Application of Systems Engineering on Defense Programs, 3.2

name: calculator

definitions.text: device that is suitable for performing arithmetic operations, but that requires human intervention to alter its stored program, if any, and to initiate each operation or sequence of operations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: A calculator performs some of the functions of a computer, but usually operates only with frequent human intervention.

name: calendar unit

definitions.text: smallest unit of time used in scheduling a project

note: Calendar units are generally in hours, days, or weeks, but can also be in quarter years, months, shifts, or even in minutes.

name: call

definitions.text: transfer of control from one software module to another, usually with the implication that control will be returned to the calling module
computer instruction that transfers control from one software module to another as in (1) and often specifies the parameters to be passed to and from the module
to transfer control from one software module to another as in (1) and, often, to pass parameters to the other module
request for service(s) or action(s) with respect to an application or a related service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.9

note: A call might concern a request for service, information or advice; disruption or error reporting (incident); request for change; assignment (for instance an instruction to start an off-schedule production run); and complaint

name: call arrow

definitions.text: arrow that enables the sharing of detail between IDEF0 models (linking them together) or within an IDEF0 model
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.23

note: The tail of a call arrow is attached to the bottom side of a box. One or more page references are attached to a call arrow.

name: call by name

definitions.text: method for passing parameters, in which the calling module provides to the called module a symbolic expression representing the parameter to be passed, and a service routine evaluates the expression and provides the resulting value to the called module

note: Because the expression is evaluated each time its corresponding formal parameter is used in the called module, the value of the parameter can change during the execution of the called module.

name: call by reference

definitions.text: a method for passing parameters, in which the calling module provides to the called module the address of the parameter to be passed

note: With this method, the called module has the ability to change the value of the parameter stored by the calling module.

name: call by value

definitions.text: method of passing parameters, in which the calling module provides to the called module the actual value of the parameter to be passed

note: With this method, the called module cannot change the value of the parameter as stored by the calling module.

name: call graph

definitions.text: diagram that identifies the modules in a system or computer program and shows which modules call one another

note: The result is not necessarily the same as that shown in a structure chart.

definitions.text: ordered list of arguments used in a call to a software module
page reference attached to a call arrow
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.24

definitions.text: decomposition diagram invoked by a calling box and identified by a page reference attached to a call arrow
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.25

name: calling box

definitions.text: box that is detailed by a decomposition diagram that is not the box's child diagram
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.26

note: A call arrow is attached to the bottom of a calling box.

definitions.text: sequence of computer instructions and, possibly, data necessary to perform a call to another module
controller area network
documented software size measurement method submitted for conformity evaluation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14143-2:2011 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement — Part 2: Conformity evaluation of software size measurement methods to ISO/IEC 14143-1, 3.1

name: candidate key

definitions.text: attribute, or combination of attributes, of an entity for which no two instances agree on the values
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2- 1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.14

note: [key style]

definitions.text: model that contains the essential elements of effective processes for one or more disciplines and describes an evolutionary improvement path from ad hoc, immature processes to disciplined, mature processes with improved quality and effectiveness
process that can satisfy specified product quality, service quality, and process-performance objective

name: capacity

definitions.text: degree to which the maximum limits of a product or system parameter meet requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.2.3

note: Parameters can include the number of items that can be stored, the number of concurrent users, the communication bandwidth, throughput of transactions, and size of database.

definitions.text: type of performance efficiency testing conducted to evaluate the level at which increasing load (of users, transactions, data storage, etc.) compromises a test item's ability to sustain required performance
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.5

definitions.text: spending by an enterprise to acquire tangible infrastructure or facilities items, such as furniture, computers, and the like

note: does not include acquisition of consumable supplies or of items to be included in finished products for sale

name: capsule

definitions.text: configuration of engineering objects forming a single unit for the purpose of encapsulation of processing and storage
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 8.1.4

example: a virtual machine (e.g. a process)

definitions.text: engineering object which manages the engineering objects in a capsule
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 8.1.5

definitions.text: cost analysis requirements description
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

name: cardinality

definitions.text: constraint on the number of entity instances that are related to the subject entity through a relationship
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.text: specification of how many instances of a first class can or are required to exist for each instance of a second (not necessarily distinct) class, and how many instances of a second class can or are required to exist for each instance of a first class
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2- 1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.15

note: For each direction of a relationship, the cardinality can be constrained.

definitions.text: constraint that limits the number of instances that can be associated with each other in a relationship
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.16

definitions.text: constraint that limits the number of members in a collection
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.16

definitions.text: set of a many-sorted algebra
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.6

definitions.text: single-entry, single-exit multiple-way branch that defines a control expression, specifies the processing to performed for each value of the control expression, and returns control in all instances to the statement immediately following the overall construct

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14102:2008 Information Technology - Guideline for the evaluation and selection of CASE tools, 4

name: CASE needs

definitions.text: organizational requirements which are met by CASE tool characteristics
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 14471:2007 Information technology — Software engineering — Guidelines for the adoption of CASE tools, 2.1.3

note: These characteristics are detailed in ISO/IEC 14102:2008. They include management process, development process, maintenance, documentation, configuration management, quality assurance, verification, validation, environment needs, CASE tool integrability, quality characteristics, acquisition needs, implementation needs, support indicators, and certification requirements.

name: CASE tool

definitions.text: software tool used for computer-aided software engineering (CASE)
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.1-2002 (R2007) IEEE Guide for CASE Tool Interconnections-Classification and Description, 3.3

definitions.text: software product that can assist software engineers by providing automated support for software life-cycle activities
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14102:2008 Information Technology - Guideline for the evaluation and selection of CASE tools, 3.2

definitions.text: software product that can assist software and system engineers by providing automated support for software and system engineering life-cycle activitie
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15940:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software Engineering Environment Services, 2.3

note: A CASE tool can provide support in only selected functional areas or in a wide variety of functional areas.

definitions.text: to treat an object of one type as an object of another type
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.17

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 12182:2015 Systems and software engineering — Framework for categorization of IT systems and software, and guide for applying it, 3.5

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 12182:2015 Systems and software engineering — Framework for categorization of IT systems and software, and guide for applying it, 3.6

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 12182:2015 Systems and software engineering — Framework for categorization of IT systems and software, and guide for applying it, 3.9

existence dependency between the stimulus of a behavior and the various responses that are caused to occur

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: Specifically, the CDIF meta-metamodel defines an Entity-Relationship-Attribute model that is used to constru and define both metamodels and the CDIF meta-metamodel itself

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 154 1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: The CDIF semantic metamodel defines an Entity-Relationship-Attribute model that is used to construct an define models used in systems development.

name: CDIF transfer

definitions.text: combination of a particular syntax, a particular encoding of that syntax, and a metamodel
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: In other words, a complete definition of the format and contents of a transfer.

definitions.text: transfer file conforming to ISO/IEC 15475
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.1

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

name: CDIF transfer syntax and encoding

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: The combination of SYNTAX.1 and ENCODING.1 forms the initial CDIF transfer syntax and encoding.

definitions.text: critical design review
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.1:2014 IEEE Standard for Application of Systems Engineering on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: a property of the central limit theorem predicting that the data observations in a distribution will tend to group around a central location. The three typical measures of central tendency are the mean, median, and mode
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: certification

definitions.text: third-party attestation related to products, processes, systems, or persons
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.15

definitions.text: a written guarantee that a system or component complies with its specified requirements and is acceptable for operational use
formal demonstration that a system or component complies with its specified requirements and is acceptable for operational use
process of confirming that a system or component complies with its specified requirements and is acceptable for operational use

example: written authorization that a computer system is secure and is permitted to operate in a defined environment
note: Certification is applicable to all objects of conformity assessment except for conformity assessment bodies themselves, to which accreditation is applicable. Certification of a management system is sometimes also called registration.

name: certification artifact

definitions.text: tangible results from a certification process

example: inspection checklists, metrics, problem reports

name: certification body

definitions.text: body certifying persons against the requirements in ISO/IEC 24773:2008, including the development and maintenance of a Scheme
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24773:2008 Software engineering -Certification of software engineering professionals -Comparison framework, 3.2

definitions.text: third-party conformity assessment body operating certification schemes
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.16

note: A certification body can be non-governmental or governmental (with or without regulatory authority)

name: certification criteria

definitions.text: set of standards, rules, or properties to which an asset must conform in order to be certified to a certain level

note: Certification criteria are defined by a certification policy. Certification criteria can be specified as a set of certification properties that must be met.

definitions.text: process of assessing whether an asset conforms to predetermined certification criteria appropriate for that class of asset

activities by which a certification body establishes that a person fulfills specified competence requirements, including application, evaluation, decision on certification, surveillance and recertification, and use of certificates and logos or marks
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29154:2013, Software engineering — Guide for the application of ISO/IEC 24773:2008 (Certification of software engineering professionals — Comparison framework), 3.1

name: certification property

definitions.text: statement about some feature or characteristic of an asset that can be assessed as being true or false during a certification process

note: Properties can relate to what an asset is, what it does, or how it relates to its operating environment. An assessment of a certification quality factor is accomplished by assessing the underlying certification properties.

name: certification scheme

definitions.text: specific certification requirements related to specified categories of persons, to which the same particular standards and rules and the same procedures apply
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29154:2013, Software engineering — Guide for the application of ISO/IEC 24773:2008 (Certification of software engineering professionals — Comparison framework), 3.2

definitions.text: certification system related to specified products, to which the same specified requirements, specific rules, and procedures apply
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.17

note: [ISO/IEC 17024]

name: certification scheme owner

definitions.text: person or organization that is responsible for developing and maintaining a specific certification scheme
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.18

note: The certification scheme owner can be the certification body itself, a governmental authority, trade association, group of certification bodies, or other.

definitions.text: cumulative flow diagram
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 3

definitions.text: one or more tasks submitted to the SUT in a defined sequence
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.3

definitions.text: sequence of actions within an activity where, for each adjacent pair of actions, occurrence of the first action is necessary for the occurrence of the second action
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.1.1

name: chain type

definitions.text: classification of chains which is defined by the sequence of tasks types
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.4

note: The emulated users submit only chains of specified chain types to the SUT.

definitions.text: the modification of an existing application comprising additions, changes and deletions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

name: change authority

definitions.text: configuration board
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 15846:1998 Information technology — Software life cycle processes — Configuration Management, 4.2

note: Disposition is made by a designated change authority traditionally given the name "Change/Configuration Control Board". This authority can approve a proposed change, thus converting it to an approved modification, or can disapprove a proposed change, or can defer a decision.

definitions.text: a process whereby modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project are identified, documented, approved, or rejected
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a formally chartered group responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to a project, and for recording and communicating such decisions
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: change control procedure

definitions.text: actions taken to identify, document, review, and authorize changes to a software or documentation product that is being developed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.8

note: The procedures ensure that the validity of changes is confirmed, that the effects on other items are examined, and that those people concerned with the development are notified of the changes.

definitions.text: a set of procedures that describes how modifications to the project deliverables and documentation are managed and controlled
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: selective dump of those storage locations whose contents have changed since some specified time or event
a comprehensive list of changes made during the project. This typically includes dates of the change and impacts in terms of time, cost, and risk
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: judicious use of means to effect a change, or a proposed change, to a product or service
collection of objects that have been changed and approved and will be transferred to the production environment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.10

definitions.text: a count that measures the work-output arising from modifications to an existing application that add, change or delete user functions delivered when the project is complete
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

definitions.text: record containing details of which configuration items are affected and how they are affected by an authorized change
a formal proposal to modify any document, deliverable, or baseline
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: formal procedure for submitting a request for an adjustment of a configuration item
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 18018:2010 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for configuration management tool capabilities, 3.5

definitions.text: collection of objects which can undergo change as the result of a release
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.11

definitions.text: temporary information processing system used to facilitate the transition from an operational system to its successor
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: channel

definitions.text: approach to distributing products and services from the original supplier to the end-user organization
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.3

definitions.text: configuration of stubs, binders, protocol objects and interceptors providing a binding between a set of interfaces to basic engineering objects, through which interaction can occur
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 8.1.8

note: Typical channels for software include direct, VAR, OEM, reseller, and educational reseller. Bindings that require channels are referred to as distributed bindings in the engineering language; bindings between engineering objects that do not require channels (e.g. between engineering objects in the same cluster) are referred to as local bindings.

definitions.text: maximum amount of information that can be transferred on a given channel per unit of time; usually measured in bits per second or in baud.

name: channel partner

definitions.text: person or entity working with a software licensor or another person/entity within the channel who facilitates the sale of software to the end-user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.4

example: original equipment manufacturer (OEM), reseller, vendor

definitions.text: letter, digit, or other symbol that is used to represent information
member of a set of elements that is used for the representation, organization, or control of data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: character set

definitions.text: collection of characters used in an encoding to represent terminal symbols
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: The character set used is significant in the encoding of text and string meta-attributes for a CDIF transfer

definitions.text: data type whose members can assume the values of specified characters and can be operated on by character operators, such as concatenation

name: characteristic entity

definitions.text: meta-entity that provides additional attribution for another meta-object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Informatio technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: Other common names for characteristic entity are attributive entity and dependent entity. Each instance of a characteristic meta-entity is logically only related to one instance of one other meta-object, therefore an importer coul incorporate the meta-attributes of a characteristic meta-entity with those of the 'owning' meta-object, where the owning m object is the one to which the characteristic meta-entity is related with a cardinality of 1:1

definitions.text: a distinctive property of the FUR that is important for identifying the functional domain to which a specific set of FUR belongs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 14143-5:2004 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement — Part 5: Determination of functional domains for use with functional size measurement, 3.1

a technique for systematically reviewing materials using a list for accuracy and completeness
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: testing conducted in the operational or support environment to ensure that a software product performs as required after installation.
point in a computer program at which program state, status, or results are checked or recorded

object template derived from the state and structure of an engineering object that can be used to instantiate another engineering object, consistent with the state of the original object at the time of checkpointing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 8.1.20

name: checkpointing

definitions.text: creating a checkpoint
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 8.1.21

note: Checkpoints can only be created when the engineering object involved satisfies a pre-condition stated in a checkpointing policy

definitions.text: dual entity that is a class and an object at the same time

Instances of powertypes are usually viewed as clabjects, since they are objects (because they are instances of a type, the powertype) and also classes (subtypes of the partitioned type).

definitions.text: a request, demand, or assertion of rights by a seller against a buyer, or vice versa, for consideration, compensation, or payment under the terms of a legally binding contract, such as for a disputed change

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineerin — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.2

note: Claims usually relate to specified versions of a product. The statement of a claim does not mean that the only possible intent or desire is to show it is true. Sometimes claims are made for the purpose of evaluating whether they are true or false or undertaking an effort to establish what is true. In its entirety, a claim is an unambiguous declaration of an assertion with any associated conditionality, giving explicit details including limitations on values and uncertainty. It could be about the future, present, or past. A safety goal is an instance of a claim.

name: commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS)

definitions.text: [software] product available for purchase and use without the need to conduct development activities
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 90003:2014 Software engineering — Guidelines for the application of ISO 9001:2008 to computer software, 3.4; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.4

note: COTS software product includes the product description (including all cover information, data sheet, web site information, etc.), the user documentation (necessary to install and use the software), the software contained on a computer sensible media (disk, CD-ROM, internet downloadable, etc.). Software is mainly composed of programs and data. This definition applies also to product descriptions, user documentation and software which are produced and supported as separate manufactured goods, but for which typical commercial fees and licensing considerations do not apply.

definitions.text: software product defined by a market-driven need, commercially available, and whose fitness for use has been demonstrated by a broad spectrum of commercial users

name: commit message

definitions.text: explanatory message accompanying a commit

note: often contains a brief description of the change and its rationale; names of contributors, reviewers, or approvers; a reference to third-party software from which the change was obtained; a schedule for integrating it to other branches; and a reference to the issue identifier associated with the change

name: commit privileges

definitions.text: person's authority to commit changes

note: Sometimes privileges are associated with a specific part of the product (for example, artwork or documentation) or a specific branch.

name: commit war

definitions.text: series of conflicting and mutually reversing commits introduced by developers who disagree on how a particular element is being coded

note: sometimes starts with a hostile backout.

name: commit window

definitions.text: period during which commits are allowed for a specific branch

note: In some development environments, commit windows for a maintenance branch might only open for short periods a few times a year.

name: commitment

note: The enterprise object(s) participating in an action of commitment can be parties or agents acting on behalf of a party or parties. In the case of an action of commitment by an agent, the principal becomes obligated.

name: compensatory model

definitions.text: multiple-criteria decision-making model, in which a composite measure is composed of individually weighte terms and where criteria (also referred to as attribute terms) with a high value can compensate for those of a low value in proportion to each weight

note: A compensatory model suggests that improving the more important measures (those with a higher weighting) is more likely to increase or improve the overall composite value than improving the less important ones. This model assumes that the weight (influence level) of criteria remains the same regardless of the measured level of the criteria.

definitions.text: one of the parts that make up a system

definitions.text: object that encapsulates its own template, so that the template can be interrogated by interaction with the component
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.26

definitions.text: specific, named collection of features that can be described by an IDL component definition or a corresponding structure in an interface repository
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

definitions.text: functionally or logically distinct part of a system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group ArchitectureDriven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

note: A component can be hardware or software and can be subdivided into other components. Component refers to a part of a whole, such as a component of a software product or a component of a software identification tag. The terms module, component, and unit are often used interchangeably or defined to be subelements of one another in different ways depending upon the context. The relationship of these terms is not standardized. A component can be independently managed or not, from the end-user or administrator's point of view

name: component home

definitions.text: meta-type that acts as a manager for instances of a specified component type
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

note: Component home interfaces provide operations to manage component life cycles, and optionally, to manage associations between component instances and primary key values.

definitions.text: testing of groups of related components.
standard that describes the characteristics of data or program components subdivided into other components
testing of individual hardware or software components [IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1;
client that is defined using the IDL extensions in the component model
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

name: composite key

definitions.text: key comprising of two or more attributes
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.38

note: [key style]

definitions.text: variable derived from a set of operations of a construct's multi-item measures defined according to a construct specification (either reflective or formative) that is the way in which the latent variable representing the construct of interest is linked to its measures
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33003:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Requirements for process measurement frameworks, 3.4

definitions.text: object expressed as a composition
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.2

definitions.text: task containing nested objects

name: composite type

definitions.text: data type each of whose members is composed of multiple data items

example: a data type called PAIRS whose members are ordered pairs (x,y)

definitions.text: combination of two or more objects yielding a new object, at a different level of abstraction
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.1.a

definitions.text: combination of two or more behaviors yielding a new behavior
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.1.b

definitions.text: both the set of artifacts that constitute the unit of component implementation, and the definition of this aggregate entity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

definitions.text: use of the value of a variable in any type of statement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.4

definitions.text: component specified in a computational viewpoint that has a control interface and declared sets of (a) operation interfaces in which it plays a server role (facets), (b) operation interfaces in which it plays a client role (receptacles), (c) operation interfaces originating announcements carrying notifications of typed events (event sources), (d) operation interfaces consuming announcements carrying notifications of typed events (event sinks), (e) operation interfaces supporting accessors and mutators for attributes (attributes)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.16

definitions.text: container for a declared set of computational component types that has a management interface at which it can be requested to create a computational component of one of the types and add it to the container's content, delete a computational component from the container, list the computational components it currently contains, and list the computational factories it provides
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.17

definitions.text: factory that returns an interface reference to the computational object it creates
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.15

name: computational interface template

definitions.text: interface template for either a signal interface, a stream interface, or an operation interface
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746- 3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.10

note: A computational interface template comprises a signal, a stream or an operation interface signature as appropriate, a behavior specification and an environment contract specification.

definitions.text: object template which comprises a set of computational interface templates which the object template can instantiate, a behavior specification, and an environment contract specification
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.9

definitions.text: viewpoint on an ODP system and its environment which enables distribution through functional decomposition of the system into objects which interact at interfaces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 4.1.1.3

name: computer

definitions.text: functional unit that can perform substantial computations, including numerous arithmetic operations and logic operations without human intervention
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: A computer can consist of a stand-alone unit or several interconnected units

definitions.text: facility that includes personnel, hardware, and software, organized to provide information processing services
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: crime committed through the use, modification, or destruction of hardware, software, or data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: computer generation

definitions.text: category in a historical classification of computers based mainly on the technology used in their manufacture
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

example: first generation based on relays or vacuum tube, the second on transistors, the third on integrated circuits

definitions.text: methods and techniques for construction, manipulation, storage, and display of images by means of a computer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: computer instruction

definitions.text: statement in a programming language, specifying an operation to be performed by a computer and the addresses or values of the associated operands
loosely, any executable statement in a computer program

example: Move A to B

definitions.text: language designed to enable humans to communicate with computers
data processing nodes and their interconnections for the purpose of data communication
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: engineering discipline that measures the performance of computer systems and investigates methods by which that performance can be improved
combination of computer instructions and data definitions that enable computer hardware to perform computational or control functions

syntactic unit that conforms to the rules of a particular programming language and that is composed of declarations and statements or instructions needed for a certain function, task, or problem solution
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: brief description of a computer program that provides sufficient information for potential users to determine the appropriateness of the program to their needs and resources

name: computer resource

definitions.text: element of a data processing system needed to perform required operations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

example: storage devices, input-output units, one or more processing units, data, files, and program

name: computer resource allocation

definitions.text: assignment of computer resources to current and waiting jobs

example: the assignment of main memory, input/output devices, and auxiliary storage to jobs executing concurrently in a computer system

definitions.text: computer equipment, programs, documentation, services, facilities, supplies, and personnel available for a given purpose
branch of science and technology that is concerned with information processing by means of computers
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: functionally or logically distinct part of a computer software configuration item, typically an aggregate of two or more software units
aggregation of software that is designated for configuration management and treated as a single entity in the configuration management process
system containing one or more computers and associated software
system containing one or more components and elements such as computers (hardware), associated software, and data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25024:2015 Systems and software engineering - Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) - Measurement of data, 4.3

definitions.text: pertaining to a technique or process in which a computer does part of the work
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: computer-aided design (CAD)

definitions.text: use of a computer to design a device or a system, display it on a computer monitor or printer, simulate its operation, and provide statistics on its performance

note: The computer is provided with data concerning the item to be designed, how it is to function, and the rules for the way in which the different components can be joined.

name: computer-aided software engineering (CASE)

definitions.text: use of computers to aid in the software engineering process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15940:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software Engineering Environment Services, 2.2

example: the application of software tools to software design, requirements tracing, code production, testing, document generation, and other software engineering activities

name: computer-based software system (CBSS)

definitions.text: software system running on a computer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.5

note: A CBSS can be a data processing system as seen by human users at their terminals or at equivalent machine user-interfaces. It includes hardware and all software (system software and application software) which is necessary for realizing data processing functions required by its users

definitions.text: automation by means of computers
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: to automate by means of computers
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology -- Vocabulary

definitions.text: facility designed to provide computer services to a variety of users through the operation of computers and auxiliary hardware and through services provided by the facility's staff

name: computing device

definitions.text: functional unit that can perform substantial computations, including numerous arithmetic operations and logic operations with or without human intervention
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.6

note: A computing device can consist of a stand-alone unit, or several interconnected units. It can also be a device that provides a specific set of functions, such as a phone or a personal organizer, or more general functions such as a laptop or desktop computer.

definitions.text: visible and quantifiable abstractions of computing system characteristics having attributes in isolation and relationships in context
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.1-2002 (R2007) IEEE Guide for CASE Tool Interconnections-Classification and Description, 3.4

name: computing system tool

definitions.text: computer-based tool used by a developer or maintainer organization for creating and evolving dynamic system
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.1-2002 (R2007) IEEE Guide for CASE Tool Interconnections-Classification and Description, 3.5

example: not only traditional CASE tools, but also requirements tools, verification and validation tools, design tools, and documentation tools.

definitions.text: communications security
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: derivation of a system concept through the application of analysis.

name: concept of operations

definitions.text: verbal and/or graphic statement, in broad outline, of an organization's assumptions or intent in regard to an operation or series of operations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.12; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.11; ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.4

note: It provides the basis for bounding the operating space, system capabilities, interfaces and operating environment. The concept of operations frequently is embodied in long-range strategic plans and annual operational plans. In the latter case, the concept of operations in the plan covers a series of connected operations to be carried out simultaneously or in succession. The concept is designed to give an overall picture of the organization operations.

definitions.text: user-oriented document that describes a system's operational characteristics from the end user's viewpoin

name: concept phase

definitions.text: period of time in the system life cycle during which the user needs are identified and system concepts are described and evaluated

note: precedes the requirements phase

definitions.text: a data model that illustrates the data groups as they are seen by the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

definitions.text: model of the concepts relevant to some endeavor
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.39

definitions.text: system design activity concerned with specifying the logical aspects of the system organization, its processes, and the flow of information through the system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: concern

definitions.text: [system] interest in a system relevant to one or more of its stakeholders
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.13; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.12; ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Architecture description, 3.7

definitions.text: interest in something relevant to one or more of its stakeholders
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 12182:2015 Systems and software engineering — Framework for categorization of IT systems and software, and guide for applying it, 3.2

note: A concern pertains to any influence on a system in its environment, including developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

definitions.text: software attributes that provide implementation of a function with a minimum amount of code
property of a system in which events can occur independently of each other, and hence are not ordered
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.7

name: concurrent

definitions.text: pertaining to the occurrence of two or more activities within the same interval of time, achieved either by interleaving the activities or by simultaneous execution
problem, process, system, or application in which many activities happen in parallel, the order of incoming events is not usually predictable, and events often overlap

note: A concurrent system or application has many threads of control.

definitions.text: diagram depicting a network of concurrent tasks and their interfaces in the form of asynchronous and synchronous message communication, event synchronization, and access to passive information-hiding object

name: concurrent elaboration

definitions.text: life cycle process instances are enacted concurrently during the project, and the information items and artefacts produced by these process instances evolve concurrently
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30103:2015 Software and Systems Engineering - Lifecycle Processes - Framework for Product Quality Achievement, 3.1

note: This is referred to as concurrent elaboration of information items.

definitions.text: multiset of transition modes is concurrently enabled if all the involved input places contain enough tokens to satisfy the sum of all of the demands imposed on them by each input arc annotation evaluated for each transition mode in the multiset
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.10

definitions.text: description of the concurrent tasks in a system or subsystem in terms of their interfaces and interconnections
syntax used in the STL both for defining simple conditions and for compounding simple conditions to define more complex conditions
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.3-2004 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying Software Behavior

definitions.text: measurable qualitative or quantitative attribute that is stipulated for a requirement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.5

definitions.text: description of a contingency to be considered in the representation of a problem, or a reference to other procedures to be considered as part of the condition
definitions.reference: ISO 5806:1984 Information processing — Specification of single-hit decision tables, 3.6

definitions.text: true or false logical predicate
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.3-2004 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying Software Behavior

definitions.text: logical predicate involving one or more behavior model elements
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.4- 2008 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying System Behavior, 3.10

definitions.text: Boolean expression containing no Boolean operators
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.6

definitions.text: indication of the relevance of a condition to a particular rule
definitions.reference: ISO 5806:1984 Information processing — Specification of single-hit decision tables, 3.8

definitions.text: list of all the conditions to be considered in the description of a problem
definitions.reference: ISO 5806:1984 Information processing — Specification of single-hit decision tables, 3.1

definitions.text: information supplied with every product to which it is relevant
jump that takes place only when specified conditions are met
the process of obtaining seller responses, selecting a seller, and awarding a contract
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: representation of how the uncertainties inherent in a project decrease over the duration of the project
degree to which a product or system ensures that data are accessible only to those authorized to have access
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.6.1

definitions.text: arrangement of a computer system or component as defined by the number, nature, and interconnections of its constituent parts
in configuration management, the functional and physical characteristics of hardware or software as set forth in technical documentation or achieved in a product
arrangement of a system or network as defined by the nature, number, and chief characteristics of its functional units
requirements, design, and implementation that define a particular version of a system or system component
t manner in which the hardware and software of an information processing system are organized and interconnected
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: collection of objects able to interact at interfaces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 10.2

definitions.text: in configuration management, an independent examination of the configuration status to compare with the physical configuration2. detailed review of processes, product definition information, documented verification of compliance with requirements, and an inspection of products to confirm that products have achieved their required attributes or conform to released product configuration definition information
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.1

name: configuration baseline

definitions.text: configuration information formally designated at a specific time during the life of a product, product component, service, or service component

note: Configuration baselines, plus approved changes from those baselines, constitute the current configuration information.

definitions.text: element of configuration management, consisting of the evaluation, coordination, approval or disapproval, and implementation of changes to configuration items after formal establishment of their configuration identification
group of people responsible for evaluating and approving or disapproving proposed changes to configuration items, and for ensuring implementation of approved changes
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: qualified personnel who evaluate, for approval or disapproval, all proposed changes to the current developmental baseline
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: element of configuration management, consisting of selecting the configuration items for a system and recording their functional and physical characteristics in technical documentation
current approved technical documentation for a configuration item as set forth in specifications, drawings, associated lists, and documents referenced therein
document used in configuration management, providing an accounting of the configuration items that make up a product

name: configuration item (CI)

definitions.text: item or aggregation of hardware, software, or both that is designated for configuration management and treated as a single entity in the configuration management process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.14; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.13

definitions.text: component of an infrastructure or an item which is or will be under control of configuration management
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.7

definitions.text: aggregation of work products that is designated for configuration management and treated as a single entity in the configuration management process
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: entity within a configuration that satisfies an end use function and that can be uniquely identified at a given reference point
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.7

definitions.text: item or aggregation of software that is designed to be managed as a single entity and its underlying components, such as documentation, data structures, scripts
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.12

definitions.text: any system element or aggregation of system elements that satisfies an end use function and is designated by the acquirer for separate configuration control
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.1:2014 IEEE Standard for Application of Systems Engineering on Defense Programs, 3.1

note: Configuration items can vary widely in complexity, size and type, ranging from an entire system including all hardware, software and documentation, to a single module or a minor hardware component.

definitions.text: document used in configuration management, describing the development status of a configuration item based on the results of configuration audits and design reviews

discipline applying technical and administrative direction and surveillance to: identify and document the functional and physical characteristics of a configuration item, control changes to those characteristics, record and report change processing and implementation status, and verify compliance with specified requirements
definitions.reference: IEEE 828- 2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: technical and organizational activities, comprising configuration identification, control, status accounting and auditing
definitions.reference: IEEE 828- 2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: coordinated activities to direct and control the configuration
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 18018:2010 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for configuration management tool capabilities, 3.7

definitions.text: person(s) or group designated to be responsible for assuring that configuration management activities are planned and carried out
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: specific type of repository for CM information, usually a data store, used to record attributes of configuration items, and the relationships between configuration items, throughout their lifecycle
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: database containing all the relevant details of each configuration item and details of the important relationships between them
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.8

definitions.text: discipline of identifying the components of a continually evolving system to control changes to those components and maintaining integrity and traceability throughout the life cycle2. a subsystem of the overall project management system. It is a collection of formal documented procedures used to apply technical and administrative direction and surveillance to: identify and document the functional and physical characteristics of a product, result, service, or component; control any changes to such characteristics; record and report each change and its implementation status; and support the audit of the products, results, or components to verify conformance to requirements. It includes the documentation, tracking systems, and defined approval levels necessary for authorizing and controlling changes
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: configuration status accounting (CSA)

definitions.text: element of configuration management that consists of the recording and reporting of information needed to manage a configuration effectively
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 18018:2010 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for configuration management tool capabilities, 3.10

note: This information includes a listing of the approved configuration identification, the status of proposed changes to the configuration, and the implementation status of approved changes.

name: conflict

definitions.text: change in one version of a file that cannot be reconciled with the version of the file to which it is applied

note: can occur when versions from different branches are merged or when two committers work concurrently on the same file.

definitions.text: handling, controlling, and guiding a conflictual situation to achieve a resolution
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: conformance

definitions.text: within the quality management system, a general concept of delivering results that fall within the limits that define acceptable variation for a quality requirement
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: For conformance to be meaningful, the specified requirements accurately represent stakeholder requirements.

definitions.text: reference point at which behavior can be observed for the purposes of conformance testing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746- 2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 10.7

definitions.text: In the cost of quality framework, conformance work is done to compensate for imperfections that prevent organizations from completing planned activities correctly as essential first-time work. Conformance work consists of actions that are related to prevention and inspection
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: demonstration that specified requirements relating to a product, process, system, person or body are fulfilled
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.21

definitions.text: systematic examination of the extent to which a product, process, or device fulfills specified requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.4

definitions.text: document that describes the conduct and results of the evaluation carried out for a Ready to Use software product (RUSP)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.4

definitions.text: pathway for the propagation of information
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.3-2004 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying Software Behavior

definitions.text: capability of a system or device to be attached to other systems or devices without modification
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: concept of operations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.2

definitions.text: pertaining to the occurrence of two sequential events or items without the intervention of any other event or item; that is, one immediately after the other

name: consequence

definitions.text: outcome of an event
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.1

definitions.text: effect (change or non-change), usually associated with an event or condition or with the system and usually allowed, facilitated, caused, prevented, changed, or contributed to by the event, condition, or system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-1:2013 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 1: Concepts and vocabulary, 3.4.1

definitions.text: outcome of an event affecting objectives
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.3

note: The outcome can be a loss or a benefit, or neither, and can be expressed qualitatively or quantitatively.

definitions.text: degree of uniformity, standardization, and freedom from contradiction among the documents or parts of a system or component
software attributes that provide uniform design and implementation techniques and notations
without internal conflicts
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.3

name: consistent state

definitions.text: point at which processing has been fully executed, the Functional User Requirement has been satisfied, and there is nothing more to be done
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.10

example: The Functional User Requirement is to print a check and mark the appropriate account as paid. If only part of the Functional User Requirement is completed (e.g., only printing the check or only marking it as paid), the application is not in a consistent state. The printing of a check without marking the account as paid causes an inconsistency in the application as does marking it as paid without printing it.

name: consolidation of an entitlement

definitions.text: process of combining two or more entitlements into a single, unified entitlement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.5

note: Entitlements can be consolidated to simplify understanding of the current position or as the result of a licensor negotiation. The entitlement schema enables the recording of entitlement consolidations.

name: consolidation tag

definitions.text: type of tag used to represent a grouping of multiple other tags

example: In entitlement management, a consolidation tag can be used to facilitate subsequent creation of children tags with entitlement quantities which do not match the original granted entitlements

name: constant

definitions.text: quantity or data item whose value cannot change
instance whose identity is known at the time of writing
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.40

definitions.text: specification that an attribute or participant property value, once assigned, shall not be changed, or that an operation shall always provide the same output argument values given the same input argument values.
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.40

definitions.text: numeric or string value that does not change during program execution
reference name for a numerical, lexical, or externally specified fixed (unchanging) value
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.3-2004 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying Software Behavior

example: the data item FIVE, with an unchanging value of 5
note: The identity of a constant state class instance is represented by #K, where K is an integer or a name.

definitions.text: addressing inflation and deflation by using cash flow amounts that represent money values which are referenced to a fixed time (typically, the beginning of a project)

individual item to be controlled that is a constituent (part) of a larger configuration item, such as a reference model, hardware prototype or software build
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

name: constraint

definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes

definitions.text: restriction on software life cycle process (SLCP) development
rule that specifies a valid condition of data
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.41

definitions.text: responsibility that is a statement of facts that are required to be true in order for the constraint to be met
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.41

definitions.text: restriction on the value of an attribute or the existence of any object based on the value or existence of one or more others

definitions.text: a limiting factor that affects the execution of a project, program, portfolio, or process
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: A constraint is a factor that is imposed on the solution by force or compulsion and can limit or modify the design changes.

name: construct

definitions.text: concept, such as the abstract idea, image, underlying theme, or subject matter, that one wishes to measure using process assessments
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33003:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Requirements for process measurement frameworks, 3.5

note: In process measurement frameworks, constructs (also refers to latent constructs) are theoretical concepts, such as the process quality characteristics and process attributes. The meaning that one assigns to a construct is its theoretical definition, which describes its distinct dimensions (facets).

name: construction

definitions.text: process of writing, assembling, or generating assets
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3

definitions.text: activity in software development consisting of detailed design, coding, unit testing, and debugging

note: the collection of activities focused on creating source code

definitions.text: organization or person who buys the software package
event sink
