definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: independent evaluator

definitions.text: individual or organization that performs an evaluation independently from developers and acquirers
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25040:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Evaluation process, 4.30

note: The individual or organization acting as developer or acquirer for the target system to be evaluated cannot become the independent evaluator for the system. The independent evaluator can be an organization.

definitions.text: state class that is not a dependent state class
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.85

definitions.text: verification and validation performed by an organization that is technically, managerially, and financially independent of the development organization
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

definitions.text: address that must be added to the contents of an index register to obtain the address of the storage location to be accessed
an indication denoting the estimated size of an application or project, based exclusively on a conceptual data model or a data model in the third normal-form
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

name: indicator

definitions.text: measure that provides an estimate or evaluation of specified attributes derived from a model with respect to defined information needs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.10; ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.13

definitions.text: device or variable that can be set to a prescribed state based on the results of a process or the occurrence of a specified condition

example: a flag or semaphore

definitions.text: numerical or categorical result assigned to an indicator
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.11

definitions.text: computer program error that has not been purposely inserted as part of an error-seeding proces

name: indirect address

definitions.text: address that identifies the storage location of another address

note: The designated storage location can contain the address of the desired operand or another indirect address; the chain of addresses eventually leads to the operand.

definitions.text: computer instruction that contains indirect addresses for its operands
human effort that is not directly associated with the units being produced

name: indirect measure

definitions.text: measure of an attribute that is derived from measures of one or more other attributes

note: An external measure of an attribute of a computing system (such as the response time to user input) is an indirect measure of attributes of the software as the measure will be influenced by attributes of the computing environment as well as attributes of the software.

definitions.text: person who receives output from a system, but does not interact with the system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.6

definitions.text: a proof of correctness technique in which assertions are written describing program inputs, outputs, and intermediate conditions, a set of theorems is developed relating satisfaction of the input assertions to satisfaction of the output assertions, and the theorems are proved or disproved using proof by induction
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual

definitions.text: set of failures that occur during the early-failure period of a system or componen
a graphical representation of situations showing causal influences, time ordering of events, and other relationships among variables and outcomes
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: persons or groups that are not directly related to the acquisition or use of the product, but, who can affect the course of the project, positively or negatively, due to their position in the customer organization
testing conducted in accordance with test plans and procedures that have not been reviewed and approved by a customer, user, or designated level of management

name: information

definitions.text: knowledge that is exchangeable amongst users, about things, facts, concepts, and so on, in a universe of discourse
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 3.2.6

definitions.text: In information processing, knowledge concerning objects, such as facts, events, things, processes, or ideas, including concepts, that within a certain context has a particular meaning
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: Although information will necessarily have a representation form to make it communicable, it is the interpretation of this representation (the meaning) that is relevant in the first place.

definitions.text: systematic investigation of information and its flow in a real or planned system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: information architecture

definitions.text: (human-centered) structure of an information space and the semantics for accessing required task objects, system objects and other information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.8

note: The appropriate combination of organization, labeling, navigation schemes and retrieval mechanisms within an information space will facilitate task completion and efficient access to content.

definitions.text: set of metamodel and model instances found in a CDIF transfer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.text: process of developing content that meets the needs of the audience
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 26511:2011 Systems and software engineering — Requirements for managers of user documentation, 4.11

definitions.text: repeatable processes used to assemble and organize data across a spectrum of sources
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: software development technique in which each module's interfaces reveal as little as possible about the module's inner workings and other modules are prevented from using information about the module that is not in the module's interface specification2. containment of a design or implementation decision in a single module so that the decision is hidden from other modules

name: information item

definitions.text: separately identifiable body of information that is produced, stored, and delivered for human use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30103:2015 Software and Systems Engineering - Lifecycle Processes - Framework for Product Quality Achievement, 3.3; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.23; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.22; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.11

definitions.text: separately identifiable body of information that is produced and stored for human use during a system or software life cycle
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25063:2014 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: Context of use description

note: An information item can be produced in several versions during a system, software, or service life cycle.

definitions.text: information included in an information item, associated with a system, product or service, to satisfy a requirement or need
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.13

name: information item type

definitions.text: group of information items consistent with a pre-arranged set of generic criteria
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.14

example: A 'plan' is the information item type for all plans and 'report' is the information item type for all reports.

definitions.text: in an information processing system, the functions of controlling the acquisition, analysis, retention, retrieval, and distribution of information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: facilities, processes and procedures used to collect, store and distribute information between producers and consumers of information in physical or electronic format
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: insight necessary to manage objectives, goals, risks, and problems
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.12; ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.14

name: information processing

definitions.text: systematic performance of operations upon information, which includes data processing and can include operations such as data communication and office automation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: The term information processing is not a synonym for data processing

definitions.text: the set of functions required by the commissioning user of the application software product (excluding any technical and quality requirements)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 1.1

definitions.text: one or more data processing systems and devices, such as office and communication equipment, that perform information processing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: information product

definitions.text: one or more indicators and their associated interpretations that address an information need
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.13

example: a comparison of a measured defect rate to planned defect rate along with an assessment of whether or not the difference indicates a problem

definitions.text: collection of all the infrastructure tools, software applications, non-automated elements, data sets, user documentation, and organizational structures which serve to supply information to the business
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350- 2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.20

name: information radiator

definitions.text: a large and frequently updated display of project information that is continually visible to the project team and other stakeholders
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

example: burndown charts, cumulative flow diagrams, parking lot diagrams

definitions.text: actions, methods, and procedures for obtaining information on a given subject from stored data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: information security

definitions.text: preservation of confidentiality, integrity and accessibility of information

note: In addition, other properties such as authenticity, accountability, non-repudiation and reliability can also be involved.

definitions.text: single or a series of unwanted or unexpected information security events that have a significant probability of compromising business operations and threatening information security
information processing system, together with associated organizational resources such as human, technical, and financial resources, which provides and distributes information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: all of the functions (input, output, transport, processing, and storage) of an application, databases, technical facilities, and manual procedures which support business processes
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.21

definitions.text: one or more computer systems and communication systems together with associated organizational resources such as human, technical, and financial resources that provide and distribute information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25024:2015 Systems and software engineering - Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) - Measurement of data, 4.24

name: information technology

definitions.text: resources required to acquire, process, store and disseminate information

note: includes Communication Technology (CT) and the composite term Information and Communication Technology (ICT)

definitions.text: temporary endeavor undertaken to create or change a unique information technology product, system, or service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29155-1:2011 Systems and software engineering — Information technology project performance benchmarking framework — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 2.7

definitions.text: viewpoint on an ODP system and its environment that focuses on the semantics of information and information processing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 4.1.1.2

name: Information-based domain (IBD)

definitions.text: realm of activity for which information is the most valuable asset
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24744:2014 Software Engineering — Metamodel for development methodologies, 3.1

note: Information creation, manipulation, and dissemination are the most important activities within information based domains. Typical information-based domains are software and systems engineering, business process reengineering, and knowledge management

definitions.text: hardware and software environment to support computer system and software design, development, and modification

semantic notion by which the responsibilities (properties and constraints) of a subclass are considered to include the responsibilities of a superclass, in addition to its own, specifically declared responsibilities
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.86

definitions.text: attribute that is a characteristic of a class by virtue of being an attribute of a generic ancestor
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.87

definitions.text: attribute that is a characteristic of a category entity by virtue of being an attribute in its generic entity or a generic ancestor entity
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.87

definitions.text: error carried forward from a previous step in a sequential process

name: initial Ent

definitions.text: Ent that is referenced by later Ents
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.14

note: The initial Ent is typically a record of the first transaction between software licensor and end customer. An initial Ent is a type of primary Ent.

definitions.text: a function point count carried out at the beginning of a project
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

definitions.text: investment required just to start an activity
set of initial place markings given with the high-level net definition
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.14.1

definitions.text: special marking of a place, defined with the high-level net
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.14.2

definitions.text: bootstrap loader used to load that part of an operating system needed to load the remainder of the operating system
estimated risk before applying risk reduction measures
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.6

name: initialization section

definitions.text: optional list of unconditional actions to be executed sequentially before the first condition is examined
definitions.reference: ISO 5806:1984 Information processing — Specification of single-hit decision tables, 3.13

note: It can be written in the row which follows that of the table heading.

definitions.text: to set a variable, register, or other storage location to a starting value
object causing a communication
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.4.1

definitions.text: those processes performed to define a new project or a new phase of an existing project by obtaining authorization to start the project or phase
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: person or organization that has both the ability and authority to start a project
point where the recoverability of the system under test (SUT) is tested by injecting a disturbance while a workload is being run
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25045:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Evaluation module for recoverability, 4.3

definitions.text: sequence of computer instructions that is physically contiguous with the instructions that logically precede and follow it
number of allowed instances of the relationship from the viewpoint of a single instance of the data object planning a role
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15476-4:2005 Information technology — CDIF semantic metamodel — Part 4: Data models, 6.6.2

definitions.text: data received from an external source
pertaining to a device, process, or channel involved in receiving data from an external source
to receive data from an external source
to provide data from an external source
loosely, input data
in an IDEF0 model, that which is transformed by a function into output
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.62

definitions.text: any item, whether internal or external to the project that is required by a process before that process proceeds. May be an output from a predecessor process
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: data entered into an information processing system or any of its parts for storage or processing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: process of entering data into an information-processing system or any of its parts for storage or processing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: arc directed from a place to the transition
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.1.1

definitions.text: designation given to an operation argument that will always have a value at the invocation of the operation

name: input arrow

definitions.text: arrow or arrow segment that expresses IDEF0 input
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.63

note: That is, an object type set whose instances are transformed by a function into output. The arrowhead of an input arrow is attached to the left side of a box.

definitions.text: logical expression specifying one or more conditions that program inputs must satisfy in order to be valid
loopback of output from one function to be input for another function in the same diagram
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.64

definitions.text: place connected to the transition by an input arc
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — Highlevel Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.20.1

definitions.text: effort to develop software products, expressed in units of staff-hour

name: input routine

definitions.text: those activities required to obtain the logical record to be processed next

note: If there are no more logical records to be processed, the end-of-input condition becomes tru

name: input-process-output

definitions.text: software design technique that consists of identifying the steps involved in each process to be performed and identifying the inputs to and outputs from each step

note: A refinement called hierarchical input-process-output identifies the steps, inputs, and outputs at both genera and detailed levels of detail

definitions.text: diagram of a software system or module, consisting of a rectangle on the left listing inputs, a rectangle in the center listing processing steps, a rectangle on the right listing outputs, and arrows connecting inputs to processing steps and processing steps to outputs

name: inspection

definitions.text: visual examination of a software product to detect and identify software anomalies, including errors and deviations from standards and specifications
definitions.reference: IEEE 1028-2008 IEEE Standard for Software Reviews and Audits, 3.3

definitions.text: a static analysis technique that relies on visual examination of development products to detect errors, violations of development standards, and other problems3. examining or measuring to verify whether an activity, component, product, result, or service conforms to specified requirements
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: Inspections are peer examinations led by impartial facilitators who are trained in inspection techniques. Determination of remedial or investigative action for an anomaly is a mandatory element of a software inspection, although the solution could be determined outside the inspection meeting. Types include code inspection and design inspection.

name: inspection-based evaluation

definitions.text: evaluation based on the judgment of one or more evaluators who examine or use a system to identify potential usability problems, including deviations from established criteria
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.10

example: heuristic evaluation, cognitive walkthrough, standards inspection, pluralistic walkthrough, consistency inspection
note: The evaluators making the inspections typically are usability specialists, but can also include end users and members of the design team. Inspection-based evaluation can be conducted by machines in some cases, e.g., when consistency with required terminology is being evaluated. Established criteria typically include user requirements, usability guidelines in standards, design conventions contained in manufacturer guidelines and style guides, task models to be supported, as well as standardized principles.

definitions.text: a process to observe performance of contracted work or promised product against agreed to requirements
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be successfully installed or uninstalled in a specified environment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.8.2

definitions.text: type of portability testing conducted to evaluate whether a test item or set of test items can be installed as required in all specified environments
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.19

definitions.text: period of time in the software life cycle during which a software product is integrated into its operational environment and tested in this environment to ensure that it performs as required
document that provides the information necessary to install a system or component, set initial parameters, and prepare the system or component for operational use
an application function point count related to a set of installed systems
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

definitions.text: discrete, bounded thing with an intrinsic, immutable, and unique identity
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.89

definitions.text: individual occurrence of a type
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.text: mapping of an activity that processes all of its input information and generates all of its output information
of a type, an <X> that satisfies the type
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.21

definitions.text: set of operations, described specifically, used in the execution of a particular benchmarking according to a given method
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29155-1:2011 Systems and software engineering — Information technology project performance benchmarking framework — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 2.6

definitions.text: mapping from the instances of a class to the instances of a value class
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.90

definitions.text: mapping from the (cross product of the) instances of the class and the instances of the input argument types to the (cross product of the) instances of the other (output) argument types
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.91

definitions.text: responsibility that applies to each instance of the class individually
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.92

definitions.text: process of substituting specific data, instructions, or both into a generic program unit to make it usable in a computer program2. of an <X> template, an <X> produced from a given <X> template and other necessary information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.16

definitions.text: identification, for each instance of a life cycle process, of the success criteria, artefact-specific activities and tasks needed to achieve the process outcomes, and the competencies needed to perform these tasks, based on the characteristics and requirements of the target system element
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30103:2015 Software and Systems Engineering - Lifecycle Processes - Framework for Product Quality Achievement, 3.5

definitions.text: knowledge from accepted sources, including standards, academic sources, domain and industry bodies of knowledge and organizational knowledge
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30103:2015 Software and Systems Engineering - Lifecycle Processes - Framework for Product Quality Achievement, 3.4

definitions.text: ingrained way of doing business that an organization follows routinely as part of its corporate culture
register that indicates the location of the next computer instruction to be executed
process of fetching a computer instruction from memory and executing it
number and arrangement of fields in a computer instruction
number of words, bytes, or bits needed to store a computer instruction
word or part of a word used to alter a computer instruction
complete set of instructions recognized by a given computer or provided by a given programming language
time it takes a computer to fetch an instruction from memory and execute it
usage mode that is intended to teach the use of software in performing tasks
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.25

definitions.text: in software and system testing, to install or insert devices or instructions into hardware or software to monitor the operation of a system or component
devices or instructions installed or inserted into hardware or software to monitor the operation of a system or component
data type whose members can assume only integer values and can be operated on only by integer arithmetic operations, such as addition, subtraction, and multiplication
to combine software components, hardware components, or both into an overall system2. to pull in the changes from one child branch into its parent
small piece of semiconductive material that contains interconnected electronic elements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: set of software tools or applications to provide comprehensive facilities for software development

name: integrated repository

definitions.text: planned and controlled storage of information pertinent to the systems engineering effort
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 24748- 4:2016, Systems and software engineering-Life cycle management-Part 4: Systems engineering planning, 4.6

note: The integrated repository typically includes key data, e.g., schema, models, tools, technical management decisions, process analysis information, requirement changes, process and product metrics, trade-offs and other analyses

name: integrated team

definitions.text: group of people with complementary skills and expertise who are committed to delivering specified work products in timely collaboration

note: Integrated team members provide skills and advocacy appropriate to all phases of the work products' life and are collectively responsible for delivering work products as specified. An integrated team includes empowered representatives from organizations, disciplines, and functions that have a stake in the success of the work products.

definitions.text: process of combining software components, hardware components, or both into an overall system
progressive linking and testing of programs or modules in order to ensure their proper functioning in the complete system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: integration testing

definitions.text: testing in which software components, hardware components, or both are combined and tested to evaluate the interaction among them
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.14

note: commonly used for both the integration of components and the integration of entire systems

definitions.text: degree to which a system, product, or component prevents unauthorized access to, or modification of, computer programs or data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.6.2

definitions.text: independent person or organization responsible for certifying compliance with the integrity-level requirement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-1:2013 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 1: Concepts and vocabulary, 3.5.4

name: integrity level

definitions.text: value representing project-unique characteristic, such as complexity, criticality, risk, safety level, security level, desired performance, and reliability, that define the importance of the system, software, or hardware to the user
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.15

definitions.text: degree to which software complies or must comply with a set of stakeholder-selected software and/or software-based syste characteristics defined to reflect the importance of the software to its stakeholders
symbolic value representing a degree of compliance within an integrity level scheme
claim of a system, product, or element that includes limitations on a property's values, the claim's scope of applicability, and the allowable uncertainty regarding the claim's achievement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-1:2013 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 1: Concepts and vocabulary, 3.3.1

definitions.text: required degree of confidence that the system-of-interest meets th associated integrity level claim
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.7

note: Generally, the intention is that maintaining limitations on a property's values related to the relevant items will result in maintaining system risks within limits. The words 'integrity level' form an indivisible label and do not depend on a concept of integrity by itself. An integrity level is different from the likelihood that the integrity level claim is met but they are closely related. The word 'confidence' implies that the definition of integrity levels can be a subjective concept. integrity levels are defined in terms of risk and hence, cover safety, security, financial and any other dimension of risk that is relevant to the system-of-interes

definitions.text: independent person or organization responsible for certifying compliance with the integrity level requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.8

definitions.text: claim representing a requirement for a risk reduction measure identified in the risk treatment process of the system-of-interest
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.10

definitions.text: person or organization responsible for defining integrity levels and integrity level requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026- 3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.9

definitions.text: set of requirements that, when met, will provide a level of confidence in the associated integrity level claim commensurate with the associated integrity level
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.11

definitions.text: set of specified requirements imposed on aspects related to a system, product, or element and associated activities in order to show the achievement of the assigned integrity level (that is, meeting its claim) within the required limitations on uncertainty; this includes the evidence to be obtained
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-1:2013 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 1: Concepts and vocabulary, 3.3.2

definitions.text: set of system characteristics (such as complexity, risk, safety level, security level, desired performance, reliability, and/or cost) selected as important to stakeholders, and arranged into discrete levels of performance or compliance (integrity levels), to help define the level of quality control to be applied in developing or delivering the software.

name: intellectual property

definitions.text: output of creative human thought process that has some intellectual or informational value

example: microcomputer design or computer program
note: Intellectual property can be protected by patents, copyrights, trademarks, or trade secrets.

definitions.text: bi-directional two-wire serial bus that provides a communication link between integrated circui

name: interaction

definitions.text: action that takes place with the participation of the environment of the object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 8.3

definitions.text: identity of phenomena existing over some period of time at the interface between two units, caused by one unit and affecting the other unit
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.4-2008 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying System Behavior, 3.15

note: The identity is expressed in relevant phenomenological terms. Generally, an interaction identity can be categorized as energy transfer, matter transfer, or information transfer.

name: interaction alias

definitions.text: relationship in a build specification that matches an interaction instance in one port with an interaction instance in another port
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.4-2008 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying System Behavior, 3.16

note: The interaction alias is used to indicate identity or compatibility of matching interactions at two ports of a port couple or a port alias. In a port alias, both interactions have the same direction. In a port coupling, the interactions have opposite directions. This provides an element of "model bookkeeping" necessary for permitting models developed independently for different units to be integrated into a unified composite model.

definitions.text: subset of the objects participating in a binding managed by the group function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 13.4.1.1

definitions.text: location at which there exists a set of interfaces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 8.12

definitions.text: pertaining to a system or mode of operation in which each user entry causes a response from or action by the system
when the user communicates with the computer in a conversational-type manner
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

name: interactive language

definitions.text: nonprocedural language in which a program is created as a result of interactive dialog between the user and the computer system

note: The system provides questions, forms, and so on, to aid the user in expressing the results to be achieved.

name: interactive system

definitions.text: combination of hardware, software and/or services that receives input from and communicates output to users
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25063:2014 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: Context of use description

note: This includes, where appropriate, packaging, branding, user documentation, online help, support and training.

definitions.text: reference point at which an external physical storage medium can be introduced into the system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746- 2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 15.3.4

definitions.text: association between a computing system tool and something in the environment that affects both endpoints, though not necessarily in the same way
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.1-2002 (R2007) IEEE Guide for CASE Tool InterconnectionsClassification and Description, 3.7

definitions.text: property by which members of an interconnection perspective are characterized
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.2-2006 IEEE Recommended Practice for CASE Tool Interconnection — Characterization of Interconnections, 3.6

definitions.text: collection of interconnections to a CASE tool that have a common kind of endpoint in the environment
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.2-2006 IEEE Recommended Practice for CASE Tool Interconnection — Characterization of Interconnections, 3.7

definitions.text: subset of interconnections that share common features in an interconnection group
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.2-2006 IEEE Recommended Practice for CASE Tool Interconnection — Characterization of Interconnections, 3.8

definitions.text: shared boundary between two functional units, defined by various characteristics pertaining to the functions, physical signal exchanges, and other characteristics
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: hardware or software component that connects two or more other components for the purpose of passing information from one to the other
to connect two or more components for the purpose of passing information from one to the other
to serve as a connecting or connected component as in (2)
declaration of the meaning and the signature for a property or constraint
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.93

definitions.text: shared boundary across which information is passed
task's external specification
abstraction of the behavior of an object that consists of a subset of the interactions of that object together with a set of constraints on when they can occur
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 8.5

definitions.text: description of a set of possible operations that a client is allowed to request of an object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-1:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 1: Interfaces, 5.3.5

definitions.text: named set of operations that characterize the behavior of an entity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group Architecture-Driven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

definitions.text: in configuration management, the administrative and technical procedures and documentation necessary to identify functional and physical characteristics between and within configuration items provided by different developers, and to resolve problems concerning the specified interfaces

in configuration management, the process of identifying all functional and physical characteristics relevant to the interfacing of two or more configuration items provided by one or more organizations and ensuring that proposed changes to these characteristics are evaluated and approved prior to implementation

name: interface design document (IDD)

definitions.text: documentation that describes the architecture and design interfaces between system and components
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.16

definitions.text: description of the architecture and design of interfaces between system and components

note: These descriptions include control algorithms, protocols, data contents and formats, and performance.

definitions.text: requirement that specifies an external item with which a system or system component must interact, or that sets forth constraints on formats, timing, or other factors caused by such an interaction

name: interface requirements specification (IRS)

definitions.text: documentation that specifies requirements for interfaces between or among systems and components
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.17

note: These requirements include constraints on formats and timing.

definitions.text: role of a community, identifying behavior which takes place with the participation of objects that are not members of that community
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.3.5

definitions.text: set of action signatures associated with the interactions of an interface
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.15

name: interface specification

definitions.text: description of essential functional, performance, and design requirements and constraints at a common boundary between two or more system elements2. document that specifies the interface characteristics of an existing or planned system or component

note: This includes interfaces between humans and hardware or software, as well as interfaces between humans themselves.

definitions.text: task that is part of the application, which interfaces to the external environment
testing conducted to evaluate whether systems or components pass data and control correctly to one another
type satisfied by any object that satisfies a particular interface
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-2:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 2: Interoperability, 3.2.18

name: interim function point count

definitions.text: a count to determine the size of an interim enhancement during a new development project or an enhancement project
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

note: i.e., a count to determine the scope of an addition, a change, or a deletion of functional specifications. Both the change in the application function point count and the project function point count can be the subject of this count.

name: interleave

definitions.text: to alternate the elements of one sequence with the elements of one or more other sequences so that each sequence retains its identity

example: to alternately perform the steps of two different tasks in order to achieve concurrent operation of the tasks

definitions.text: system or software product of the development process that is used as inputs to other stages of the development process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25041: 2012 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Evaluation guide for developers, acquirers and independent evaluators, 4.10

definitions.text: profile targeted at very small entities (VSEs) involved in the development of more than one project in parallel with more than one work team
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.30

definitions.text: needs that can be specified as quality requirements by internal measures

name: intermediate system or software product

definitions.text: product of the system or software development process that is used as input to another stage of its development process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.15

example: static and dynamic models, other documents and source code

definitions.text: temporary or unpredictable fault in a component
action which takes place without the participation of the environment of the object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 8.3

definitions.text: arrow connected at both ends (source and use) to a box in a diagram
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.65

name: internal attribute

definitions.text: measurable property of an entity which can be derived purely in terms of the entity itself

note: Internal attributes are those that relate to the internal organization of the software and its development.

definitions.text: means of synchronization between two tasks

name: internal logical file (ILF)

definitions.text: user-recognizable group of logically related data or control information maintained within the boundary of the application being measured
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.39

definitions.text: a logical group of permanent data seen from the perspective of the user that an application uses and maintains
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

note: The primary intent of an ILF is to hold data maintained through one or more elementary processes of the application being counted. An internal logical file is a type of base functional component.

name: internal measure

definitions.text: measure of the product itself, either direct or indirect

note: The number of lines of code, complexity measures, the number of faults found in a walk through and the Fog Index are all internal measures made on the product itself.

name: internal measure of software quality

definitions.text: measure of the degree to which a set of static attributes of a software product satisfies stated and implied needs for the software product to be used under specified conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.16; ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.7

example: Complexity measures and the number, severity, and failure frequency of faults found in a walkthrough are internal software quality measures made on the product itself.
note: Static attributes include those that relate to the software architecture, structure and its components. Static attributes can be verified by review, inspection, simulation, or automated tools.

definitions.text: totality of attributes of a product that determine its ability to satisfy stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14598-1:1999 Information technology — Software product evaluation — Part 1: General overview, 4.15

definitions.text: category of the task-structuring criteria addressing how internal objects are mapped to internal tasks and when an internal task is activated
variability defined from an engineer's perspective and not visible to customers
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26555:2015 Software and systems engineering — Tools and methods for product line technical management, 3.6

definitions.text: standard that is adopted by an international standardizing/standards organization and made available to the public
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 2.11

note: [ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2]

definitions.text: process of developing information so that it is suitable for an international audience
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.26

definitions.text: worldwide interlinked computer systems and networks connected by gateways that enable the transfer of data between them
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 4.13

name: interoperability

definitions.text: degree to which two or more systems, products or components can exchange information and use the information that has been exchanged
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.3.2

definitions.text: ability for two or more ORBs to cooperate to deliver requests to the proper object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-2:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 2: Interoperability, 3.2.19

definitions.text: capability to communicate, execute programs, and transfer data among various functional units in a manner that requires the user to have little or no knowledge of the unique characteristics of those units
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: capability of objects to collaborate, that is, the capability mutually to communicate information in order to exchange events, proposals, requests, results, commitments and flows
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.5

note: Interoperability is used in place of compatibility in order to avoid possible ambiguity with replaceability.

definitions.text: testing conducted to ensure that a modified system retains the capability of exchanging information with systems of different types, and of using that information
ability to establish and maintain relationships with other people
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: to translate and execute each statement or construct of a computer program before translating and executing the next
computer program that translates and executes each statement or construct of a computer program before translating and executing the next
computer instructions and data definitions expressed in a form that can be recognized and processed by an interpreter
a quality management planning tool, the interrelationship digraphs provide a process for creative problem solving in moderately complex scenarios that possess intertwined logical relationships
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: interrogation

definitions.text: interaction consisting of one interaction, the invocation, initiated by a client object, resulting in the conveyance of information from that client object to a server object, and requesting a function to be performed by the server object, followed by a second interaction, the termination, initiated by the server object, resulting in the conveyance of information from the server object to the client object in response to the invocation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 7.1.4

example: request/response exchange
note: In interrogations, invocations and terminations are always paired. Announcements do not have terminations. Thus there is no possibility of an operation consisting of an invocation followed by a sequence of associated terminations.

definitions.text: suspension of a process to handle an event external to the process
to cause the suspension of a process
loosely, an interrupt request
functional unit (integrated circuit) that determines the source and priority of interrupt requests and manages their execution
delay between a computer system's receipt of an interrupt request and its handling of the request
mask used to enable or disable interrupts by retaining or suppressing bits that represent interrupt requests

name: interrupt priority

definitions.text: importance assigned to a given interrupt request

note: This importance determines whether the request will cause suspension of the current process and, if there are several outstanding interrupt requests, which will be handled first.

definitions.text: signal or other input requesting that the currently executing process be suspended to permit performance of another process

routine that responds to interrupt requests by storing the contents of critical registers, performing the processing required by the interrupt request, restoring the register contents, and restarting the interrupted process

name: interval scale

definitions.text: scale in which the measurement values have equal distances corresponding to equal quantities of the attribute

example: Cyclomatic complexity has the minimum value of one, but each increment represents an additional path. The value of zero is not possible.

definitions.text: a formal or informal approach to elicit information from stakeholders by talking to them directly
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: reference point at which an interface can be established to allow communication between two or more systems
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 15.3.3

definitions.text: managed network operating within an organization with controlled and limited access
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 4.14

note: More than one connected or isolated intranet can exist within an organization.

definitions.text: specification that a property is total (i.e., mandatory), single-valued, and constant
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.94

name: intrinsic relationship

definitions.text: relationship that is total, single-valued, and constant from the perspective of (at least) one of the participating classes, referred to as a dependent class
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.95

example: A transaction has an intrinsic relationship to its related account, because it makes no sense for an instance of a transaction to "switch" to a different account, since that would change the very nature of the transaction.
note: Such a relationship is considered to be an integral part of the essence of the dependent class.

definitions.text: of an <X>, instantiating not achieved by an action of objects in the model
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.19

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.28

name: invariant schema

definitions.text: set of predicates on one or more information objects which must always be true
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 6.1.1

note: The predicates constrain the possible states and state changes of the objects to which they apply. Thus, an invariant schema is the specification of the types of one or more information objects that will always be satisfied by whatever behavior the objects might exhibit.

name: inverse engineering

definitions.text: process of obtaining a high-level representation of the software from the source code

note: Inverse engineering provides a more abstract view of the system with the intent of recapturing design and requirements information.

definitions.text: generally, this term is equivalent to request for proposal. However, in some application areas, it may have a narrower or more specific meaning

name: issue

definitions.text: uniquely identifiable entry in an issue-tracking system that describes a problem or an enhancement
a point or matter in question or in dispute, or a point or matter that is not settled and is under discussion or over which there are opposing views or disagreements
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: The record of an issue includes its identifier and brief description, and often identifies the environment associated with it, its status, severity, priority, and resolution, as well as dependencies, details on replicating or solving a problem, the persons associated with it, attachments, and its change history.

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.23

note: IT infrastructure management includes all of the tasks, responsibilities and activities that aim for a correct technical operation of the information system, consisting of hardware, (system) software, and data sets. The IT infrastructure management organization is responsible for running the application software in the production environment.

definitions.text: a project life cycle where the project scope is generally determined early in the project lifecycle, but time and cost estimates are routinely modified as the project team understanding of the product increases. Iterations develop the product through a series of repeated cycles, while increments successively add to the functionality of the product

name: meaning (of a responsibility)

definitions.text: statement of what the responsibility means
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.109

note: The statement of responsibility is written from the point of view of the requester, not the implementer. The statement of responsibility states what the requester needs to know to make intelligent use of the property or constraint. That statement is complete enough to let a requester decide whether to make the request, but it stops short of explaining how a behavior or value is accomplished or derived. Meaning is initially captured using freeform natural language text in a glossary definition. It can be more formally refined into a statement of pre-conditions and post-conditions using the specificatio language.

name: merge

definitions.text: to combine different changes to the same file

note: Many systems follow the optimistic strategy of combining all lines that do not conflict.

name: merge from current

definitions.text: to merge changes from the current branch into the stable branch(es)

note: To avoid disruptive changes in a stable branch, code changes are typically first introduced into the current (development) branch, tested, and then merged back.

name: methodology element

definitions.text: simple component of a methodology
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24744:2014 Software Engineering — Metamodel for development methodologies, 3.6

note: Usually, methodology elements include the specification of what tasks, activities, techniques, models, documents, languages and/or notations can or must be used when applying the methodology. Methodology elements are related to each other, comprising a network of abstract concepts. Typical methodology elements are Capture Requirements, Write Code for Methods (kinds of tasks), Requirements Engineering, High-Level Modeling (kinds of activities), Pseudo-code, Dependenc Graphs (notations), Class, Attribute (kinds of model building blocks), Class Model, Class Diagram, Requirements Specification (kind of work products).

name: microinstruction

definitions.text: in microprogramming, an instruction that specifies one or more of the basic operations needed to carry out a machine language instruction

note: Types include diagonal microinstruction, horizontal microinstruction, vertical microinstruction.

definitions.text: in microprogramming, one of the basic operations needed to carry out a machine language instruction

name: microprogramming

definitions.text: process of designing and implementing the control logic of a computer by identifying the basic operations needed to carry out each machine language instruction and representing these operations as sequences of instructions in a special memory called control store

note: This method is an alternative to hard-wiring the control signals necessary to carry out each machine language instruction. Techniques include bit steering, compaction, residual control, single-level encoding, two-level encoding

definitions.text: addressable element in the control store of a microprogrammed computer

definitions.text: a significant point or event in a project

definitions.text: scheduled event used to measure progress

example: Major milestones for software projects can include an acquirer or managerial sign-off, baselining of a specification, completion of system integration, and product delivery. Minor milestones can include baselining of a software module or completion of a chapter of the user manual.

definitions.text: a list identifying all project milestones and normally indicates whether the milestone is mandatory or optional

note: The fault tolerance discipline distinguishes between a human action (a mistake), its manifestation (a hardware or software fault), the result of the fault (a failure), and the amount by which the result is incorrect (the error).

name: model layers
alias: 1 different layers of definition (or abstraction) used in defining the CDIF family of standards [ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002
Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2]
note: The four model layers in CDIF are user data, model, metamodel, meta-metamodel. Any given model layer provides an accurate and complete definition of all the instances that occur one layer below the given layer. For example, the meta-metamodel provides a set of definitions that are used to construct and understand the metamodel; the metamodel provides a set of definitions that are used to construct and understand a model.

definitions.text: non-developmental item.

a schedule activity that has low total float. The concept of near-critical is equally applicable to a schedule activity or schedule network path. The limit below which total float is considered near critical is subject to expert judgment and varies from project to project

definitions.text: the process of reaching final equitable settlement of all outstanding issues, claims, and disputes through negotiation

definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: nest

definitions.text: to incorporate a computer program construct into another construct of the same kind

example: to nest one subroutine, block, or loop within another; to nest one data structure within another

name: nesting

definitions.text: embedding one construct inside another

example: to embed a WHILE loop within another WHILE loop or to embed an IF test within a WHILE loop

definitions.text: general term used to describe all classes of Petri Nets

definitions.text: directed graph comprising a set of nodes of two different kinds, called places and transitions, and their interconnection by directed edges, called arcs, such that only places can be connected to transitions, and transitions to places, but never transitions to transitions, nor places to places

definitions.text: in a diagram, a point, circle, or other geometric figure used to represent a state, event, or other item of interest

definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.84

note: Strongly positive or negative terms influence the overall composite value disproportionately, although the weight stays the same. There are various non-compensatory models depending on the evaluation policy, the purpose of the composite measure, or the measurement scale.

example: software performance requirements, software external interface requirements, software design constraints, and software quality attributes.

note: An object set is a subset of the union of the members of an object type set; the set of object sets includes the empty set and the set of the union of the members of the object type set itself. An object set is modeled by an arrow segment.

definitions.text: set of all possible instantiations of a singular concept, either physical or data, within an IDEF0 model.

note: An object type set can include object types that are themselves grouped as object type sets. An object type set is designated by an arrow label.

Objectives can have different aspects (such as financial, health and safety, and environmental goals) and can apply at different levels (such as strategic, organization-wide, project, product and process). The enterprise language systematically uses the term objective, (rather than purpose) and emphasizes the need of expressing objective in measurable terms.
