name: operational concept (OpsCon)

definitions.text: verbal and graphic statement of an organization's assumptions or intent in regard to an operation or series of operations of a system or a related set of systems
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.26; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.25; ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.14

note: The operational concept is designed to give an overall picture of the operations using one or more specific systems, or set of related systems, in the organization's operational environment from the users' and operators' perspective.

definitions.text: product which functions in real conditions of operations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 14759:1999 Software engineering — Mock up and prototype — A categorization of software mock up and prototype models and their use, 3.2 e)

name: operational scenario

definitions.text: description of an imagined sequence of events that includes the interaction of the product or service with its environment and users, as well as interaction among its product or service components
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.15

note: Operational scenarios are used to evaluate the requirements and design of the system and to verify and validate the system.

definitions.text: testing conducted to evaluate a system or component in its operational environment.

name: operations

definitions.text: ongoing execution of activities that produce the same product or provide a repetitive service

example: production, manufacturing, accounting

name: operator

definitions.text: individual or organization that performs the operations of a system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.27; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.26

definitions.text: entity that performs the operations of a system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.29

definitions.text: mathematical or logical symbol that represents an action to be performed in an operation
symbol representing the name of a function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.17

definitions.text: individual or an organization that contributes to the functionality of a system and draws on knowledge, skills, and procedures to contribute the function
individual or organization that operates the system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.4

note: The role of operator and the role of user can be vested, simultaneously or sequentially, in the same individual or organization. An individual operator combined with knowledge, skills and procedures can be considered as an element of the system. An operator can perform operations on a system that is operated, or of a system that is operated, depending on whether or not operating instructions are placed within the system boundary.

name: operator manual

definitions.text: document that provides the information necessary to initiate and operate a system or component

note: Typically described are procedures for preparation, operation, monitoring, and recovery. An operator manual is distinguished from a user manual when a distinction is made between those who operate a computer system (mounting tapes, etc.) and those who use the system for its intended purpose.

definitions.text: a risk that would have a positive effect on one or more project objectives
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: opportunity cost

definitions.text: implicit cost associated with investing money in a certain activity, so that it is no longer available for investing elsewhere

note: Making an investment means that the same money cannot be invested elsewhere, where it could be earning the MARR

definitions.text: study to examine a problem and determine whether or not it requires being solved during the time period under consideration. ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary]
operational concept
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.2

definitions.text: disk which stores binary data in the form of pits which interrupt the reflection of light from a laser
estimate of the shortest activity duration that takes into account all of the known variables that could affect performance
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: optimization analysis

definitions.text: balance of competing components to achieve the best performance under the situation

note: For example, an algorithm that runs faster will typically use more memory. Optimization balances the value of a faster run time against the cost of additional memory.

name: optimizing process

definitions.text: quantitatively managed process that is improved based on an understanding of the common causes of variation inherent in the process.

note: The focus of an optimizing process is on continually improving the range of process performance through both incremental and innovative improvements.

definitions.text: syntax keyword used to specify a partial mapping
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.133

definitions.text: attribute that can have no value for an instance
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.134

definitions.text: element that can be present in a tag

name: optional nonidentifying relationship

definitions.text: nonidentifying relationship in which an instance of the child entity can exist without being related to an instance of the parent entity
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.135

confer: mandatory nonidentifying relationship. nonidentifying relationship [key style]

name: optional requirement

definitions.text: requirement of a normative document that must be fulfilled in order to comply with a particular option permitted by that document
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14143-2:2011 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement — Part 2: Conformity evaluation of software size measurement methods to ISO/IEC 14143-1, 3.6

note: An optional requirement is either: a) one of two or more alternative requirements, or b) an additional requirement that is fulfilled only if applicable and otherwise is disregarded.]

definitions.text: those verification and validation (V&V) tasks that can be added to the minimum V&V tasks to address specific application requirements
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

definitions.text: task that can be added to the minimum testing tasks to address specific requirements.
Object Request Broker
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-2:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 2: Interoperability, 3.3

definitions.text: ORB component which moves a request from a client to the appropriate adapter for the target object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-2:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 2: Interoperability, 3.2.10

definitions.text: in software design, a type of structure clash in which a program must deal with two or more data sets that have been sorted in different orders

name: ordinal scale

definitions.text: scale in which the measurement values are rankings

note: For example, the assignment of defects to a severity level is a ranking

name: organization

definitions.text: group of people and facilities with an arrangement of responsibilities, authorities and relationships
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15940:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software Engineering Environment Services, 2.4; ISO/IEC TS 24748- 1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.28; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.27

definitions.text: people and processes assembled to produce a specific output (product or service)
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.2-2006 IEEE Recommended Practice for CASE Tool Interconnection — Characterization of Interconnections, 3.9

definitions.text: person or a group of people and facilities with an arrangement of responsibilities, authorities and relationships to achieve its objectives
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.34

example: company, corporation, firm, enterprise, institution, charity, sole trader, association, or parts or combination thereof
note: An identified part of an organization (even as small as a single individual) or an identified group of organizations can be regarded as an organization if it has responsibilities, authorities and relationships. A body of persons organized for some specific purpose, such as a club, union, corporation, or society, is an organization. An organization can be public or private. The arrangement is generally orderly.

name: organization chain

definitions.text: constellation of organizations that have business relationships with one another
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.25

note: The following are two types of chains identified:  supply chains of the IT organizations that are involved in the management and operation of the application (application manager, computer center, workspace manager, network manager, business information manager, suppliers, etc.);  business chains in which the user organization using the application participates (the business process supported by the application forms part of a chain across several organizations; for example, the chain of criminal justice, the healthcare chain).

definitions.text: graphical depiction of hierarchies and interrelationships among persons working together
management level or levels responsible for managing one or more data processing or information systems organizations
A hierarchical representation of the project organization that illustrates the relationship between project activities and the organizational units that will perform those activities
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: profile targeted at very small entities (VSEs) to provide them with additional organizational management guidance
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.35

name: organizational maturity

definitions.text: extent to which an organization has explicitly and consistently deployed processes that are documented, managed, measured, controlled, and continually improved.

note: Organizational maturity can be measured via appraisals.

definitions.text: guiding principle typically established by senior management that is adopted by an organization to influence and determine decisions

name: organizational process assets

definitions.text: plans, processes, policies, procedures and knowledge bases, specific to and used by the performing organization
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: artifacts that relate to describing, implementing, and improving processes, such as policies, measurements, process descriptions, and process implementation support tools

note: The term 'process assets' is used to indicate that these artifacts are developed or acquired to meet the business objectives of the organization and that they represent investments by the organization that are expected to provide current and future business value.

definitions.text: extent to which an organizational unit consistently implements processes within a defined scope that contributes to the achievement of its business needs (current or projected)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.2

name: organizational profile

definitions.text: set of process profiles
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-3-1:2015 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 3-1: Assessment Guide, 3.3

note: Profiles conform to the organizational maturity levels that correspond to the basic, intermediate, and advanced profiles.

definitions.text: the level of an organization's ability to deliver the desired strategic outcomes in a predictable, controllable and reliable manner
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: test process for developing and managing organizational test specifications
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.23

definitions.text: document that provides information about testing for an organization, i.e. information that is not project-specifi
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.24

definitions.text: document that expresses the generic requirements for the testing to be performed on all the projects run within the organization, providing detail on how the testing is to be performed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.25

name: organizational unit

definitions.text: part of an organization that is the subject of measurement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.30

definitions.text: identified part of an organization that deploys one or more processes that operate within a coherent set of business goals and which forms the basis for the scope of an assessment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.2.14

note: An organizational unit is typically part of a larger organization, although in a small organization the organizational unit can be the whole organization.

definitions.text: address of the initial storage location assigned to a computer program in main memory
classification of software as either developed or nondeveloped
license for products or components that are created or manufactured by one company and licensed by another company
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.17

page on a website with no link from the home page or other page on the website

one-time password

pertaining to a device, process, or channel involved in transmitting data to an external destination
process by which an information processing system, or any of its parts, transfers data outside of that system or part

arc directed from the transition to a place

definitions.text: argument that has not been specified as an input argument

note: It is possible for an output argument to have no value at the time a request is made.

definitions.text: arrow or arrow segment that expresses IDEF0 output
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.90

note: That is, an object type set whose instances are created by a function by transforming the function's input. The arrowtail of an output arrow is attached to the right side of a box.

definitions.text: logical expression specifying one or more conditions that program outputs must satisfy in order for the program to be correct
place connected to the transition by an output arc
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.20.2

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

example: a report, an output file, or a message to a different application

name: outsider's viewpoint

definitions.text: perspective of a potential acquirer who does not own either an existing system nor its proposed replacement, and who evaluates the alternatives of buying the existing system at its salvage value or buying a replacement candidate system

note: allows sunk cost and salvage values to be properly accounted for in a decision to replace a system

definitions.text: exception that occurs when the result of an arithmetic operation exceeds the size of the storage location designated to receive it

name: overhead time

definitions.text: amount of time a computer system spends performing tasks that do not contribute directly to the progress of any user task

example: time spent tabulating computer resource usage for billing purposes

definitions.text: storage allocation technique in which computer program segments are loaded from auxiliary storage to main storage when needed, overwriting other segments not currently in use
computer program segment that is maintained in auxiliary storage and loaded into main storage when needed, overwriting other segments not currently in use
to load a computer program segment from auxiliary storage to main storage in such a way that other segments of the program are overwritten
routine that controls the sequencing and positioning of overlays
to assign an operator, identifier, or literal more than one meaning, depending upon the data types associated with it at any given time during program execution
ability of a property in a subclass to respecify the realization of an inherited property of the same name while retaining the same meaning

alias: 1 technique of filling out a fixed-length block of data with dummy characters, words, or records 2. dummy

note: The page reference incorporates a diagram reference to the associated diagram, the type of page, and any sequencing data needed to distinguish different pages of the same type that are associated with the same diagram.

table that identifies the location of pages in storage and gives significant attributes of those pages
uppercase letter in a page reference that denotes a specific type of model page

routine that initiates and controls the transfer of pages between main and auxiliary storage

name: paging
alias: 1 storage allocation technique in which programs or data are divided into fixed-length blocks called pages, main
storage is divided into blocks of the same length called page frames, and pages are stored in page frames, not
necessarily contiguously or in logical order 2. storage allocation technique in which programs or data are divided
into fixed-length blocks called pages, main storage is divided into blocks of the same length called page frames, and
pages are transferred between main and auxiliary storage as needed 3. transfer of pages as in (2)

name: parse

definitions.text: to determine the syntactic structure of a language unit by decomposing it into more elementary subunits and establishing the relationships among the subunits

example: to decompose blocks into statements, statements into expressions, expressions into operators and operands

definitions.text: software tool that parses computer programs or other text, often as the first step of assembly, compilation, interpretation, or analysis

name: partial

definitions.text: incomplete mapping
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.143

note: That is, some instances map to no related instance. An attribute can be declared partial, meaning it may have no value. A participant property is declared optional as part of the relationship syntax. An operation is declared partial when it has no meaning for some instances, i.e., it does not give an answer or produce a response.

definitions.text: subclass cluster in which an instance of the superclass exists without also being an instance of any of the subclasses
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.144

definitions.text: in proof of correctness, a designation indicating that a program's output assertions follow logically from its input assertions and processing steps

name: participant property

definitions.text: property of a state class that reflects that class' knowledge of a relationship in which instances of the class participate
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.145

note: When a relationship exists between two state classes, each class contains a participant property for that relationship. A participant property is a mapping from a state class to a related (not necessarily distinct) state class. The name of each participant property is the name of the role that the other class plays in the relationship, or it simply the name of the class at the other end of the relationship (as long as using the class name does not cause ambiguity). A value of a participant property is the identity of a related instance.

definitions.text: decomposition; the separation of the whole into its parts

name: party

definitions.text: organization entering into an agreement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.29; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.28

definitions.text: enterprise object modeling a natural person or any other entity considered to have some of the rights, powers and duties of a natural person
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.6.1

example: enterprise objects representing natural persons, legal entities, governments and their parts, and other associations or groups of natural persons
note: Parties are responsible for their actions and the actions of their agents. Parties to an agreement are called the acquirer and the supplier.

name: pass

definitions.text: single cycle in the processing of a set of data, usually performing part of an overall process

example: a pass of an assembler through a source program, a pass of a sort program through a set of data

name: passive I/O device

capability of a program to be executed on various types of data processing systems without converting the program to a different language and with little or no modification
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a system, product, or component can be transferred from one hardware, software or other operational or usage environment to another
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.8

definitions.text: property that the reference points of an object allow it to be adapted to a variety of configurations
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 15.4.1

definitions.text: type of testing conducted to evaluate the ease with which a test item can be transferred from one hardware or software environment to another, including the level of modification needed for it to be executed in various types of environments
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.28

definitions.text: microcomputer that can be hand-carried for use in more than one location
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: projects, programs, subportfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: post-closure activities

definitions.text: activities that occur after a software system has been formally accepted by its customer

note: These activities include, but are not limited to, lessons-learned reviews and archiving project materials

definitions.text: condition that is guaranteed to be true after a successful property request
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.147

definitions.text: constraint that must be true when a use case has ended3. predicate that a specification requires to be true immediately after the occurrence of an action
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.30

definitions.text: dump that is produced upon abnormal termination of a computer program

name: postprocessor

definitions.text: computer program or routine that carries out some final processing step after the completion of the primary process

example: a routine that reformats data for output

definitions.text: energy-saving operational state for a microcontroller unit (MCU

name: powertype

definitions.text: type, the instances of which are subtypes of another type called the 'partitioned type'
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24744:2014 Software Engineering — Metamodel for development methodologies, 3.12

example: The class TreeSpecies is a powertype of the class Tree, since each instance of TreeSpecies is also a subclass of Tree.

definitions.text: Product Parts List
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 16326:2009 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Project management, 3

definitions.text: program protection plan
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: program parts selection list
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: Problem Reporting and Resolution Planned Information.
specific type of activity that contributes to the execution of a process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.8

definitions.text: a specific type of professional or management activity that contributes to the execution of a process and that can employ one or more techniques and tools
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a technique used for constructing a schedule model in which activities are represented by nodes and are graphically linked by one or more logical relationships to show the sequence in which the activities are to be performed
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the term used in the precedence diagramming method for a logical relationship. In current usage, however, precedence relationship, logical relationship, and dependency are widely used interchangeably, regardless of the diagramming method used
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: precision

definitions.text: degree of exactness or discrimination with which a quantity is stated2. Within the quality management system, precision is a measure of exactness
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

example: a precision of 2 decimal places versus a precision of 5 decimal places

name: precompiler

definitions.text: computer program or routine that processes source code and generates equivalent code that is acceptable to a compiler

note: for example, a routine that converts structured FORTRAN to ANSI-standard FORTRAN

definitions.text: condition that is required to be true before making a property request
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.148

definitions.text: constraint that must be true when a use case is invoked
predicate that a specification requires to be true for an action to occur
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-1:1998 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference model: Overview, 9.29

definitions.text: an activity that logically comes before a dependent activity in a schedule
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: logical expression which evaluates to TRUE or FALSE, normally to direct the execution path in code
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.24

definitions.text: data use associated with the decision outcome of the predicate portion of a decision statement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.25

definitions.text: a form of project life cycle in which the project scope, and the time and cost required to deliver that scope, are determined as early in the life cycle as possible
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: metric applied during development and used to predict the values of a software quality factor
definitions.reference: IEEE 1061-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Software Quality Metrics Methodology, 2.13

name: predictive metric value

definitions.text: numerical target related to a quality factor to be met during system development
definitions.reference: IEEE 1061-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Software Quality Metrics Methodology, 2.14

note: This is an intermediate requirement that is an early indicator of final system performance. For example, design or code errors can be early predictors of final system reliability.

definitions.text: process of analyzing design alternatives and defining the architecture, components, interfaces, and timing and sizing estimates for a system or component
result of the process in (1)

review conducted to evaluate the progress, technical adequacy, and risk resolution of the selected design approach for one or more configuration items; to determine each design's compatibility with the requirements for the configuration item; to evaluate the degree of definition and assess the technical risk associated with the selected manufacturing methods and processes; to establish the existence and compatibility of the physical and functional interfaces among the configuration items and other items of equipment, facilities, software and personnel; and, as applicable, to evaluate the preliminary operational and support documents
review as in (1) of any hardware or software component

name: preparation time

definitions.text: time which elapses before the task submission
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.12

note: The event of starting the preparation time depends on the definition of the task mode of the following task.

name: preprocessor

definitions.text: computer program or routine that carries out some processing step prior to the primary process

example: a precompiler or other routine that reformats code or data for processing

definitions.text: action that establishes a rule
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.6.3

definitions.text: representation of a cash flow as a single instance at the beginning of the planning horizon
can be retrieved and viewed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.18

definitions.text: device used to present data to the intended user of a system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25024:2015 Systems and software engineering - Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) - Measurement of data, 4.30

definitions.text: to store data that are required by a computer program or routine before the program or routine is entered
use of indentation, blank lines, and other visual cues to show the logical structure of a program
an intentional activity that ensures the future performance of the project work is aligned with the project management plan
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: action to avoid or eliminate the causes or reduce the likelihood of occurrence of a potential nonconformity or other potential undesirable situation
modification of a software product after delivery to detect and correct latent faults in the software product before they become operational faults
definitions.reference: IEEE 14764-2006 Software Engineering - Software Life Cycle Processes - Maintenance, 3.8

definitions.text: maintenance performed for the purpose of preventing problems before they occur
designing a software system that is easy to maintain
continuously upgrading a system to enable it to cope with current and future changes
software that has been produced prior to or independent of the project for which the plan is prepared, including software that is obtained or purchased from outside sources
definitions.reference: IEEE 1228-1994 (R2002) IEEE Standard for Software Safety Plans, 3.1.2

name: primary Ent

definitions.text: entitlement schema (Ent) which encapsulates basic information about an entitlement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.19

note: Primary Ents have an <entType> of Initial, Consolidation, AllocationReceived, or TransferReceived. These are base Ents which allow for initial population of an Ent into an Ent library (with the exception of Consolidation, which can be used to replace several previous Ents if desired). Other Ents (called supplemental Ents) can extend the data in these base type Ents.

definitions.text: in Mk II FPA, one of the main entity-types which has the attributes that the application has been designed to process and/or store
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

definitions.text: intent that is first in importance
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.43

name: primary key

definitions.text: candidate key selected as the unique identifier of an entity
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.149

definitions.text: value that uniquely identifies component instances within the scope of the home that manages them
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

note: [key style]

name: primitive

definitions.text: lowest level for which data is collected

example: error, failure, fault, time, time interval, date, number of non-commentary source code statements, edges, and nodes
note: Primitives are directly measurable or countable, or can be given a constant value or condition for a specific measure.

definitions.text: party that has delegated (authority, a function, etc.) to another
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.6.9

definitions.text: configuration of connections between electronic components, typically using metallic paths etched on a non conducting substrate (board)
printed circuit board with embedded components and devices
documentation that is either provided in printed form, or provided in electronic form for the customer or user to print
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.33

definitions.text: a quality management planning tool used to identify key issues and evaluate suitable alternatives to define a set of implementation priorities
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: priority ceiling protocol

definitions.text: algorithm that provides bounded priority inversion

note: that is, at most one lower-priority task can block a higher-priority tas

definitions.text: interrupt performed to permit execution of a process that has a higher priority than the process currently executing
case where a task's execution is delayed because a lower priority task is blocking it
responsibility that is visible only to the class or the receiving instance of the class (available only within methods of the class)
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.150

definitions.text: known only within a single routine or module
data type whose structure and possible values are defined but are not revealed to the user of the type
computer instruction that can be executed only by a supervisory program
process reference model
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-3-1:2015 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 3-1: Assessment Guide, 4.2

name: probability

definitions.text: extent to which an event is likely to occur
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.3

definitions.text: mathematically, a real number in the scale 0 to 1 attached to a random event, related to a long-run relative frequency of occurrence or to a degree of belief that an event will occur
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.3

note: For a high degree of belief, the probability is near 1. Frequency rather than probability can be used in describing risk. Degrees of belief about probability can be chosen as classes or ranks, such as rare/ unlikely/ moderate/ likely/ almost certain, or incredible/ improbable/ remote/ occasional/ probable/ frequent.

definitions.text: a grid for mapping the probability of each risk occurrence and its impact on project objectives if that risk occurs
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: problem

definitions.text: difficulty, uncertainty, or otherwise realized and undesirable event, set of events, condition, or situation that requires investigation and corrective action
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.30; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.29

definitions.text: difficulty or uncertainty experienced by one or more persons, resulting from an unsatisfactory encounter with a system in use
definitions.reference: IEEE 1044-2009 IEEE Standard Classification for Software Anomalies, 2

definitions.text: undesirable situation concerning an application, the application management organization, its processes or working methods, which demands structural analysis of the cause and a structural solution
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.27

note: A risk factor becomes a problem when a risk metric (an objective measure) crosses a predetermined threshold (the problem trigger). The root cause is not usually known at the time a problem record is created and the problem management process is responsible for further investigation. A problem might concern a service or product or a process (-step) or any other element of the application management organization.

definitions.text: statement of a problem, which can include a description of the data, the method, the procedures, and algorithms used to solve it
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: problem report (PR)

definitions.text: document used to identify and describe problems detected in a product
definitions.reference: IEEE 14764-2006 Software Engineering - Software Life Cycle Processes - Maintenance, 3.9

note: PRs are either submitted directly to denote faults or established after impact analysis is performed on Modification Requests and faults are found.

definitions.text: in the operation of a computer system, a state in which programs other than the supervisory program can execute

name: problem-oriented language

definitions.text: programming language designed for the solution of a given class of problems

example: list processing languages, information retrieval languages, simulation languages

definitions.text: type of cohesion in which the tasks performed by a software module all contribute to a given program procedure, such as an iteration or decision process

name: procedural language

definitions.text: programming language in which the user states a specific set of instructions that the computer must perform in a given sequence

note: All widely-used programming languages are of this type.

name: procedural programming language

definitions.text: computer programming language used to express the sequence of operations to be performed by a computer.

example: COBOL

name: procedure

definitions.text: information item that presents an ordered series of steps to perform a process, activity, or task
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.19

definitions.text: portion of a computer program that is named and that performs a specific action
routine that does not return a value
specified way to carry out an activity or process [ISO/IEC 19770-1:2012 Information technology — Software asset management — Part 1: Processes and tiered assessment of conformance,
an established method of accomplishing a consistent performance or result. A procedure typically can be described as the sequence of steps that will be used to execute a process
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: A procedure defines an established and approved way or mode of conducting business in an organization. It details permissible or recommended methods in order to achieve technical or managerial goals or outcomes. When a procedure is specified as an outcome, the resulting deliverable will typically specify what must be done, by whom, and in what sequence. This is a more detailed level of specification than for a process.

definitions.text: type of functional suitability testing conducted to evaluate whether procedural instructions for interacting with a test item or using its outputs meet user requirements and support the purpose of their use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119- 1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.29

name: process

definitions.text: set of interrelated or interacting activities that transforms inputs into outputs
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.31; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.29

definitions.text: predetermined course of events defined by its purpose or by its effect, achieved under given conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: to perform operations on data
collection of steps taking place in a prescribed manner
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.3.6

definitions.text: in data processing, the predetermined course of events that occur during the execution of all or part of a program
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: executable unit managed by an operating system scheduler
system of activities, which use resources to transform inputs into outputs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.22

definitions.text: a systematic series of activities directed towards causing an end result such that one or more inputs will be acted upon to create one or more outputs
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: set of interrelated or interacting activities that use inputs to deliver an intended result
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.36

note: The term "activities" covers use of resources. A process can have multiple starting points and multiple end points. The prescribed manner can be a partially ordered sequence. A process specification can be a workflow specification. An enterprise specification can define types of processes and process templates. A process can be viewed as a specific instantiation of life cycle processes, adapted within a life cycle model, to create the service or product for the specific requirements and context of a project. When a process definition is specified as an outcome, the resulting deliverable typically specifies inputs and outputs, and gives a general description of expected activities. However, it does not include the same level of detail as for a procedure.

definitions.text: plan, usually resulting from appraisals, that documents how specific improvements targeting the weaknesses uncovered by an appraisal will be implemented
team that has the responsibility to develop and implement process improvement activities for an organization as documented in a process action plan
A process analysis follows the steps outlined in the process improvement plan to identify needed improvements
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: person or group that has primary responsibility for creating and maintaining the software life cycle process (SLCP)

name: process architecture

definitions.text: ordering, interfaces, interdependencies, and other relationships among the process elements in a standard process

note: Process architecture also describes the interfaces, interdependencies, and other relationships between process elements and external processes, such as contract management.

definitions.text: cluster of related practices in an area that, when implemented collectively, satisfies a set of goals considered important for making improvement in that area
disciplined evaluation of an organizational unit's processes against a process assessment model
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.2.15

definitions.text: determination of the extent to which the organization's standard processes contribute to the achievement of its business goals and help the organization focus on the need for continuous process improvement

name: process assessment model (PAM)

definitions.text: model suitable for the purpose of assessing a specified process quality characteristic, based on one or more process reference models
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.9; ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.38

note: Process assessment models addressing a specific process quality characteristic can include the identification of the characteristic in the title; for example, a process assessment model addressing process capability can be termed a "process capability assessment model."

name: process asset library

definitions.text: collection of information that can be useful to those who are defining, implementing, and managing processes in the organization.

example: process-related documentation such as policies, defined processes, checklists, lessons-learne documents, templates, standards, procedures, plans, and training materials.

definitions.text: measurable property of a process quality characteristic
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.3

definitions.text: observable result of achievement of a specified process attribute
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.4

definitions.text: judgment of the degree of achievement of the process attribute for the assessed process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.5

definitions.text: characterization of the ability of a process to meet current or projected business goals
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33020:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Process measurement framework for assessment of process capability, 3.1

definitions.text: range of expected results that can be achieved by following a process

name: process capability level

definitions.text: characterization of a process on an ordinal measurement scale of process capability
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33020:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Process measurement framework for assessment of process capability, 3.2

definitions.text: point on the six-point ordinal scale of process capability that represents the capability of the process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29110-2-1:2015 — Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 2-1: Framework and taxonomy, 4.39

note: Each level builds on the capability of the level below.

definitions.text: CORBA component with persistent state, which is not visible to the client, persistent identity, and behavior, which can be transactional
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-3:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Architecture Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 3: Components, 4.1

definitions.text: The PDPC is used to understand a goal in relation to the steps for getting to the goal
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: identification of a sequence of steps involving activities, constraints, and resources that are performed for a given purpose

name: process description

definitions.text: documented expression of a set of activities performed to achieve a given purpose

note: A process description provides an operational definition of the major components of a process. The description specifies, in a complete, precise, and verifiable manner, the purpose, outcomes, activities and tasks, requirements, design, behavior, or other characteristics of a process. It also can refer to procedures for determining whether these provisions have been satisfied. Process descriptions can be applicable at the project or organizational level.

name: process dimension

definitions.text: set of process elements in a process assessment model explicitly related to the processes defined in the relevant process reference model(s)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.10

note: The elements of the process dimension include processes, process purpose statements, process outcomes, and process performance indicators.

definitions.text: collection of related processes
team of specialists who facilitate the definition, maintenance, and improvement of processes used by the organization
actions taken to improve the quality of the organization's processes aligned with the business needs and the needs of other concerned parties
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.1.7

definitions.text: result of activities that better the performance and maturity of the organization's processes
actions taken to improve the quality of the organization's processes aligned with the business needs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.41

definitions.text: set of target characteristics established to guide the effort to improve an existing process in a specific, measurable way, either in terms of resultant product or service characteristics, such as quality, performance, and conformance to standards, or in the way in which the process is executed, such as elimination of redundant process steps, combination of process steps, and improvement of cycle time
a subsidiary plan of the project management plan. It details the steps for analyzing processes to identify activities that enhance their value
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: way that an organization expresses support for process improvement projects or initiatives
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 33014:2013 Information technology — Process assessment — Guide for process improvement, 3.2

definitions.text: internal structure of the software life-cycle process, to include lifecycle phases, documentation, baselines, reviews, and products
single specific and identifiable execution of a process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30103:2015 Software and Systems Engineering - Lifecycle Processes - Framework for Product Quality Achievement, 3.7; ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.2.17

name: process management

definitions.text: direction, control, and coordination of work performed to develop a product or perform a service

example: quality assurance

definitions.text: schema for use in characterizing a process quality characteristic of an implemented process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.6

definitions.text: metric used to measure characteristics of the methods, techniques, and tools employed in developing, implementing, and maintaining the software system
definitions.reference: IEEE 1061-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Software Quality Metrics Methodology, 2.15

name: process outcome

definitions.text: observable result of the successful achievement ofthe process purpose
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.27; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.32

note: An outcome is an artifact, a significant change of state or the meeting of specified constraints. An outcome statement describes one of the following: production of an artifact; a significant change in state; meeting of specified constraints, e.g., requirements, goals.

name: process owner

definitions.text: person (or team) responsible for defining and maintaining a process

note: At the organizational level, the process owner is the person (or team) responsible for the description of a standard process; at the project level, the process owner is the person (or team) responsible for the description of the defined process. A process can therefore have multiple owners at different levels of responsibility.

definitions.text: extent to which the execution of a process achieves its purpose
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.7

definitions.text: assessment indicator that supports the judgment of the process performance of a specific process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.12

definitions.text: set of process attribute ratings for an assessed process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.2.18

name: process purpose

definitions.text: high-level objective of performing the process and the likely outcomes of effective implementation of the proces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.33; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.31

note: The implementation of the process is intended to provide tangible benefits to the stakeholders.

definitions.text: ability of a process to satisfy stated and implied stakeholder needs when used in a specified context
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.8

definitions.text: measurable aspect of process quality
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.9

definitions.text: category of process attributes that are significant to process quality
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.9

definitions.text: systematic assessment and analysis of selected processes against a target process profile
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.2.19

definitions.text: set of elements in a process assessment model explicitly related to the process measurement framework for the specified process quality characteristic
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.14

definitions.text: assessment indicator that supports the judgment of the process quality characteristic of a specific process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.3.15

definitions.text: point on a scale of achievement of a process quality characteristic derived from the process attribute ratings for an assessed process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33001:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Concepts and terminology, 3.4.10

definitions.text: representation of the achieved level of a process quality characteristic derived from the process attribute ratings for an assessed process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-3-1:2015 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 3-1: Assessment Guide, 3.2

definitions.text: model comprising definitions of processes in a domain of application described in terms of process purpose and outcomes, together with an architecture describing the relationships between the processes

definitions.text: making, altering, or adapting a process description for a particular end

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.9

note: Generic product categories are hardware (e.g., engine mechanical part); software (e.g., computer program); services (e.g., transport); and processed materials (e.g., lubricant). Hardware and processed materials are generally tangible products, while software or services are generally intangible. Most products comprise elements belonging to different generic product categories. Whether the product is then called hardware, processed material, software, or service depends on the dominant element. Results could be components, systems, software, services, rules, documents, or many other items. The result could in some cases be many related individual results.

definitions.text: process of evaluating a product by manual or automated means to determine if the product has certain characteristics2. For projects that have a product as a deliverable, it is a tool to define scope that generally means asking questions about a product and forming answers to describe the use, characteristics and other the relevant aspects of what is going to be manufactured

note: It prescribes all necessary physical or form, fit, and function characteristics of a configuration item, the selected functional characteristics designated for production acceptance testing, and the production acceptance tests.

software product name, version, variant, and date information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.12

risk that a product could be defective in some specific aspect of its function, quality, or structure

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

note: In other words, the total functionality to be added, changed, or deleted. It enables those involved to determine the effort required in order to realize new software or to change the functionality of existing software. In the latter case, a project function point count pertains to the addition, change, or deletion of functions.

definitions.text: forecast project costs to be paid for that are derived from the cost baseline for total or periodic requirements, including projected expenditures plus anticipated liabilities

definitions.text: An inclusive term that describes the sum of knowledge within the profession of project management. As with other professions, such as law, medicine, and accounting, the body of knowledge rests with the practitioners and academics that apply and advance it. The complete project management body of knowledge includes proven traditional practices that are widely applied and innovative practices that are emerging in the profession. The body of knowledge includes both published and unpublished materials. This body of knowledge is constantly evolving
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: an information system consisting of the tools and techniques used to gather, integrate, and disseminate the outputs of project management processes. It is used to support all aspects of the project from initiating through closing, and can include both manual and automated systems
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: an identified area of project management defined by its knowledge requirements and described in terms of its component processes, practices, inputs, outputs, tools, and techniques
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

Project management process groups are not project phases
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: for example, a software development plan. The plan typically describes the work to be done, the resources required, the methods to be used, the procedures to be followed, the schedules to be met, and the way that the project will be organized.

definitions.text: activities concerned with the specification of the components, timing, resources, and procedures of a project

note: The project risk profile information includes the risk management context, along with the chronological record of risks and their individual risk profiles, priority ordering, risk-related measures, treatment status, contingency plans, and risk action requests. A project risk profile consists of a collection of the risk profiles of all the individual risks, which in turn includes the current and historical risk states.

name: quality assurance (QA)

definitions.text: part of quality management focused on providing confidence that quality requirements will be fulfilled
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.37; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.34

definitions.text: all the planned and systematic activities implemented within the quality system, and demonstrated as needed, to provide adequate confidence that an entity will fulfill requirements for quality
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.34

note: [ISO 9000:2005] There are both internal and external purposes for quality assurance: within an organization, quality assurance provides confidence to management; in contractual situations, quality assurance provides confidence to the customer or others. Some quality control and quality assurance actions are interrelated. Unless requirements for quality fully reflect the needs of the user, quality assurance does not necessarily provide adequate confidence.

definitions.text: characteristic of software, or a generic term applying to quality factors, quality subfactors, or metric values
definitions.reference: IEEE 1061-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Software Quality Metrics Methodology, 2.17

definitions.text: feature or characteristic that affects an item's quality3. requirement that specifies the degree of an attribute that affects the quality that the system or software must possess

definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: quality evaluation

definitions.text: systematic examination of the extent to which an entity is capable of fulfilling specified requirements

note: The requirements can be formally specified, as when a product is developed for a specific user under a contract, or specified by the development organization, as when a product is developed for unspecified users, such as consumer software, or the requirements may be more general, as when a user evaluates products for comparison and selection purposes.

definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.42

note: This definition of quality in use is similar to the definition of usability in ISO 9241-11. Before the product is released, quality in use can be specified and measured in a test environment designed and used exclusively by the intended users for their goals and contexts of use, e.g. User Acceptance Testing Environment.

definitions.text: measure of the degree to which a product or system can be used by specific users to meet their needs to achieve specific goals with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk, satisfaction and content coverage in specific contexts of use

name: ratio scale

definitions.text: scale in which the measurement values have equal distances corresponding to equal quantities of the attribute where the value of zero corresponds to none of the attribute

note: For example, the size of a software component in terms of LOC is a ratio scale, because the value of zero corresponds to no lines of code and each additional increment represents equal amounts of code.

Includes software produced and supported without typical commercial fees and licensing considerations.

name: realization

definitions.text: representation of interface responsibilities through specified algorithms and representation properties
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.156

note: The realization states "how" a responsibility is met; it is the statement of the responsibility's method. Realization consists of any necessary representation properties together with the algorithm (if any). A realization can involve representation properties or an algorithm, or both. For example, an attribute typically has only a representation and no algorithm. An algorithm that is a "pure algorithm" (i.e., without any representation properties) uses only literals; it does not "get" any values as its inputs. Finally, a derived attribute or operation typically has both an algorithm and representation properties.

definitions.text: closeness of the agreement between the results of measurements of the same measurand carried out under changed conditions of measurement

The changed conditions include the principle of measurement; method of measurement; observer; measuring instrument; reference standard; location; conditions of use; time. Reproducibility can be expressed quantitatively in terms of the dispersion characteristics of the results. Results are here usually understood to be corrected results.

Request also encompasses sentences of such requests. Logical sentences about the property values and constraints of objects are used for queries, pre-conditions, post-conditions, an responsibility realizations.
