definitions.text: document containing any combination of requirements or regulations to be met by a ready to use software product (RUSP)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.13

example: a technical or ergonomic standard, a requirements list (or model requirements specification) from a group (e.g. a market sector, technical or user association), a law or a decree

definitions.text: a description of how individual requirements meet the business need for the project
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: process through which the acquirer and the suppliers of a system discover, review, articulate, understand, and document the requirements on the system and the life cycle processes
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.18

definitions.text: use of systematic techniques, such as prototypes and structured surveys, to proactively identify and document customer and end-user need

name: requirements engineering

definitions.text: interdisciplinary function that mediates between the domains of the acquirer and supplier to establish and maintain the requirements to be met by the system, software or service of interest
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.19

note: Requirements engineering is concerned with discovering, eliciting, developing, analyzing, determining verification methods, validating, communicating, documenting, and managing requirements

definitions.text: systematic decomposition of system requirements into allocated and derived requirements, appropriately assigned to low-level functional components
activities that ensure requirements are identified, documented, maintained, communicated and traced throughout the life cycle of a system, product, or service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.20

definitions.text: provision of storing and editing capabilities, tracking history of edition, versioning, author identification, change management, time stamping, user notification for content changes, security rights control
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 24766:2009 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for requirements engineering tool capabilities, 3.3

definitions.text: a component of the project management plan that describes how requirements will be analyzed, documented, and managed
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: separation or decomposing of a top-level requirement or design into successively lower-level detaile requirements or design
period of time in the software life cycle during which the requirements for a software product are defined and documented

name: requirements review

definitions.text: process or meeting during which the requirements for a system, hardware item, or software item are presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval

note: Types include system requirements review, software requirements review.

name: requirements specification

definitions.text: document that specifies the requirements for a system or component

note: Typically included are functional requirements, performance requirements, interface requirements, design requirements, and development standards.

definitions.text: specification language with special constructs and, sometimes, verification protocols, used to develop, analyze, and document hardware or software requirements
identification and documentation of the derivation path (upward) and allocation/ flow-down path (downward) of requirements in the requirements hierarchy
discernible association between a requirement and related requirements, implementations, and verifications
traceabilities in domain and application requirements respectively and those between them
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26551:2016 Software and systems engineering — Tools and methods for product line requirements engineering, 3.18

definitions.text: table that links requirements to their origin and traces them throughout the project life cycle2. a grid that links product requirements from their origin to the deliverables that satisfy them
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: requirements traceability tool

definitions.text: software development tool that establishes a traceability among itemized software requirements specifications, design elements, code elements, and test cases

note: It also supports various associated query, analysis, and report-generation capabilities

definitions.text: confirmation by examination that requirements (individually and as a set) define the right system as intended by the stakeholders
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.22

name: requirements verification

definitions.text: confirmation by examination that requirements (individually and as a set) are well formed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.23

note: This means that a requirement or a set of requirements has been reviewed to ensure the characteristics of good requirements are achieved.

definitions.text: organization that purchases goods or services with an intention of selling them to another customer and possibly supporting them.
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.29

definitions.text: a provision in the project management plan to mitigate cost and/or schedule risk. Often used with a modifier (e.g., management reserve, contingency reserve) to provide further detail on what types of risk are meant to be mitigated
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: an analytical technique to determine the essential features and relationships of components in the project management plan to establish a reserve for the schedule duration, budget, estimated cost, or funds for a project
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: reserved word

definitions.text: word in a programming language, of which the meaning is fixed by the rules of that language and which, in certain or all contexts, cannot be used by the programmer for any purpose other than its intended one

example: IF, THEN, WHILE

definitions.text: to set a variable, register, or other storage location back to a prescribed state
microprogramming technique in which the meaning of a field in a microinstruction depends on the value in an auxiliary register
a risk that remains after risk responses have been implemented
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: risk remaining after risk treatment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.15

name: resource

definitions.text: asset that is utilized or consumed during the execution of a process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.37; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.42; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.38

definitions.text: skilled human resources (specific disciplines either individually or in crews or teams), equipment, services, supplies, commodities, materiel, budgets, or funds
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: role (with respect to that action) in which the enterprise object fulfilling the role is essential to the action, requires allocation, or can become unavailable
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15414:2015 Information technology — Open distributed processing — Reference model — Enterprise language, 6.3.5

definitions.text: any physical or virtual component of limited availability within a computer system available for a given purpose and managed by the runtime platform
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group Architecture-Driven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

example: diverse entities such as funding, personnel, facilities, capital equipment, tools, and utilities such as power, water, fuel and communication infrastructures
note: Allocation of a resource can constrain other behaviors for which that resource is essential. Resources can be reusable, renewable or consumable. A consumable resource can become unavailable after some amount of use or after some amount of time (in case a duration or expiry has been specified for the resource).

definitions.text: allocation (partitioning) of responsibility to different organizational units
a hierarchical representation of resources by category and type
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a calendar that identifies the working days and shifts on which each specific resource is available
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a bar chart showing the amount of time that a resource is scheduled to work over a series of time periods. Resource availability may be depicted as a line for comparison purposes. Contrasting bars may show actual amounts of resource used as the project progresses
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a technique in which start and finish dates are adjusted based on resource constraints with the goal of balancing demand for resources with the available supply
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: identification, estimation, allocation, and monitoring of the means used to develop a product or perform a service
task ensuring sequential access to a resource
a technique that is used to adjust the start and finish dates of activities that adjusts planned resource use to be equal to or less than resource availability
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a technique which adjusts the activities of a schedule model such that the requirement for resources on the project does not exceed certain predefined resource limits
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: resource utilization

definitions.text: degree to which the amounts and types of resources used by a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.2.2

note: Human resources are included as part of efficiency.

definitions.text: project schedule whose schedule activity, scheduled start dates and scheduled finish dates reflect expected resource availability
change by an instance from being an instance of its current subclass to being an instance of one of the other subclasses in its current cluster
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.165

definitions.text: object taking part in a communication, which is not the initiating object
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.4.2

name: response

definitions.text: reaction of the unit to a specific stimulus, depending on the current conditions on the unit's lifeline
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.4- 2008 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying System Behavior, 3.24

note: A response might be the occurrence of internally controlled interaction(s) affecting the environment (external response), or it might be the occurrence of an internally controlled change to the unit's state (internal response).

definitions.text: elapsed time between the end of an inquiry or command to an interactive computer system and the beginning of the system's response

name: responsibility

definitions.text: generalization of properties (attributes, participant properties, and operations) and constraints
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2- 1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.166

definitions.text: an assignment that can be delegated within a project management plan such that the assigned resource incurs a duty to perform the requirements of the assignment
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: An instance possesses knowledge, exhibits behavior, and obeys rules. These are collectively referred to as the instance's responsibilities. A class abstracts the responsibilities in common to its instances. A responsibility can apply to each instance of the class (instance-level) or to the class as a whole (class-level

definitions.text: a grid that shows the project resources assigned to each work package
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: method for web page construction to detect the user's screen size and orientation and dynamically change the layout accordingly
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 4.22

definitions.text: to cause a computer program to resume execution after a failure, using status and results recorded at a checkpoint
point in a computer program at which execution can be restarted following a failure
information returned to the client
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-2:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 2: Interoperability, 3.2.13

definitions.text: an output from performing project management processes and activities. Results include outcomes (e.g., integrated systems, revised process, restructured organization, tests, trained personnel, etc.) and documents (e.g., policies, plans, studies, procedures, specifications, reports, etc.)
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: record element type
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 4; ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 4

definitions.text: portion of a contract payment that is withheld until contract completion to ensure full performance of the contract terms
re-execution of test cases that previously returned a "fail" result, to evaluate the effectiveness of intervening corrective actions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.34

definitions.text: withdrawal of active support by the operation and maintenance organization, partial or total replacement by a new system, or installation of an upgraded system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.38; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.43; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.39

definitions.text: permanent removal of a system or component from its operational environment
period of time in the software life cycle during which support for a software product is terminated
a team meeting at the end of an iterative cycle or at the end of a software project to reflect on what went well, what was learned, and what should be done differently next time
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

name: retrospective trace

definitions.text: trace produced from historical data recorded during the execution of a computer program

note: This differs from an ordinary trace, which is produced cumulatively during program execution.

definitions.text: to transfer control from a software module to the module that called it
to assign a value to a parameter that is accessible by a calling module
computer instruction or process that performs the transfer in (1)
code used to influence the execution of a calling module following a return from a called module
ratio of revenue from output (product or service) to development and production costs, which determines whether an organization benefits from performing an action to produce something
value assigned to a parameter by a called module for access by the calling module
degree to which an asset can be used in more than one system, or in building other assets
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3; ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.7.2

definitions.text: in a reuse library, the characteristics of an asset that make it easy to use in different contexts, software systems, or in building different assets
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3

definitions.text: pertaining to a software module or other work product that can be used in more than one computer program or software system

name: reusable product

definitions.text: system, software, or hardware product developed for one use but having other uses, or one developed specifically to be usable on multiple projects or in multiple roles on one project
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

example: commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) products, acquirer-furnished products, products in reuse libraries, a preexisting developer products
note: Each use can include all or part of the product and can involve its modification. This term can be applied to any software or system product (for example, requirements or architectures), not just to software or system itself.

definitions.text: use of an asset in the solution of different problems
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3

definitions.text: building a software system at least partly from existing pieces to perform a new application
member of the organization's management who authorized, approves, promotes, and obtains the funding and other resources for the reuse program
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3

definitions.text: unmodified source statement obtained for the product from an external source
alternative that is described in terms of its complete cash-flow stream with expense and incom
determining what existing software will do and how it is constructed (to make intelligent changes)
a software engineering approach that derives a system's design or requirements from its code
debugging technique in which a history of program execution is recorded and then replayed under the user's control, in either the forward or backward direction
process, which can include a meeting, in which work products are presented to some stakeholders for comment or approval
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: process or meeting during which a software product is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, user representatives, or other interested parties for comment or approval
definitions.reference: IEEE 1028-2008 IEEE Standard for Software Reviews and Audits, 3.5

definitions.text: process or meeting during which a work product, or set of work products, is presented to project personnel, managers, users, customers, or other interested parties for comment or approval
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.52

definitions.text: review or audit artifacts that are expected through conduct of the technical review or audit and that can be considered elements of exit criteria
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.1

name: revocation

definitions.text: process of revoking an entitlement or entitlement schema
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.21

note: An entitlement is sometimes revoked by the organization which originally issued it. The entitlement schema (Ent) enables the recording of entitlement revocations. Specific Ent transactions can also be revoked, e.g., to correct errors or record the rescinding of entitlement allocations.

definitions.text: action taken to bring a defective or nonconforming component into compliance with requirements or specifications
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: request for change
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.2

definitions.text: request for information
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: request for proposal
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: request for quotation
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: privilege or benefit granted by a software entitlement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.22

name: risk

definitions.text: effect of uncertainty on objectives
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.16; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.44; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.40

definitions.text: combination of the probability of an abnormal event or failure and the consequence(s) of that event or failure to a system's components, operators, users, or environment
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.

definitions.text: combination of the probability of an event and its consequence
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.5

definitions.text: measure that combines both the likelihood that a system hazard will cause an accident and the severity of that accident
definitions.reference: IEEE 1228-1994 (R2002) IEEE Standard for Software Safety Plans, 3.1.3

definitions.text: function of the probability of occurrence of a given threat and the potential adverse consequences of that threat's occurrence
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.12

definitions.text: combination of the probability of occurrence and the consequences of a given future undesirable event
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012- 2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

definitions.text: uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more project objectives
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: Risk is often characterized by reference to potential events and consequences, or a combination of these. Risk is often expressed in terms of a combination of the consequences of an event and the associated likelihood of occurrence. Uncertainty is the state, even partial, of deficiency of information related to, understanding or knowledge of, an event, its consequence, or likelihood. [SOURCE: ISO Guide 73:2009]

definitions.text: recommended treatment alternatives and supporting information for one or more risks determined to be above a risk threshold
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.7

definitions.text: process of examining identified risk factors for probability of occurrence, potential loss, and potential risk handling strategies
the degree of uncertainty an entity is willing to take on, in anticipation of a reward
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: examination and documentation of the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with identified risks and their root causes, as well as the effectiveness of the risk management process
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: risk avoidance

definitions.text: course of action that removes a risk factor from further consideration
a risk response strategy whereby the project team acts to eliminate the threat or protect the project from its impact
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

example: changing the requirements, extending the schedule, or transferring the risk factor to another domain

definitions.text: a hierarchical representation of risks according to their risk categories
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: organization by sources of risk (e.g., using the RBS), the area of the project affected (e.g., using the WBS), or other useful category (e.g., project phase) to determine the areas of the project most exposed to the effects of uncertainty
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: risk category

definitions.text: a group of potential causes of risk
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

example: technical, legal, organizational, safety, economic, engineering, cost, schedule
note: A risk category is a characterization of a source of risk.

name: risk criteria

definitions.text: terms of reference by which the significance of risk is assessed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.9

definitions.text: terms of reference against which the significance of a risk is evaluated
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.17

note: Risk criteria can include associated cost and benefits, legal and statutory requirements, socio-economic and environmental aspects, the concerns of stakeholders, priorities and other inputs to the assessment.

definitions.text: technique to evaluate the degree to which the data about risks is useful for risk management
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: risk exposure

definitions.text: potential loss presented to an individual, project, or organization by a risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.10

definitions.text: function of the likelihood that the risk will occur and the magnitude of the consequences of its occurrence
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.10

definitions.text: product of probability times potential loss for a risk factor

note: Risk exposure is commonly defined as the product of a probability and the magnitude of a consequence, that is, an expected value or expected exposure.

name: risk factor

definitions.text: potential problem that would be detrimental to a planned activity, project, or program, characterized by the probability of problem occurrence (0 _ p _ 1) and a potential loss (of life, money, property, reputation, and so on) if the problem occurs

note: Both probability and potential loss might change over time.

name: risk handling

definitions.text: course of action taken in response to a risk factor

note: includes risk acceptance, risk avoidance, risk transfer, and risk mitigation.

definitions.text: organized, systematic approach to determining the risk factors associated with a planned activity, project, or program

name: risk leverage factor (rlf)

definitions.text: rlf _ (reb _ rea)/rmc, where reb is risk exposure before risk mitigation, rea is risk exposure after risk mitigation, and rmc is the risk mitigation activity's cost

note: Larger rlfs indicate better mitigation strategies.

name: risk management

definitions.text: organized process for identifying and handling risk factors

organized, analytic process to identify what might cause harm or loss (identify risks); to assess and quantify the identified risks; and to develop and, if needed, implement an appropriate approach to prevent or handle causes of risk that could result in significant harm or loss

note: The primary goal of risk management is to identify and respond to potential problems with sufficient lead-time to avoid a crisis situation. Includes initial identification and handling of risk factors as well as continuous risk management.

definitions.text: description of how the elements and resources of the risk management process will be implemented within an organization or project
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.11

definitions.text: a component of the project, program or portfolio management plan that describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: continuous process for systematically identifying, analyzing, treating, and monitoring risk throughout the life cycle of a product or service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.12

name: risk management system

definitions.text: set of elements of an organization's management system concerned with managing risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.13

note: Management system elements can include strategic planning, decision making, and other processes for dealing with risk. The culture of an organization is reflected in its risk management system.

definitions.text: objective measure associated with a risk factor to be mitigated

name: risk mitigation
note: includes executing contingency plans when a risk metric crosses a predetermined threshold (when a risk becomes an issue or results in a problem)

definitions.text: tracking identified risks, monitoring residual risks, identifying new risks, executing risk response plans, and evaluating their effectiveness throughout the project life cycle
chronological record of a risk's current and historical risk state information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.14

definitions.text: Risk reassessment is the identification of new risks, reassessment of current risks, and the closing of risks that are outdated
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: risk reduction

definitions.text: reducing the probability and/or potential impact of a risk factor

note: Risk reduction might involve research, prototyping, and other means of exploration.

definitions.text: steps taken to reduce or mitigate risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.18

name: risk register

definitions.text: a document in which the results of risk analysis and risk response planning are recorded
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

note: The risk register details all identified risks, including description, category, cause, probability of occurring, impact(s) on objectives, proposed responses, owners, and current status. It can be kept in a database.

name: risk source

definitions.text: element that, alone or in combination, has the intrinsic potential to give rise to risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.19

note: A hazard in ISO Guide 73:2009 is an instance of a risk source. A fault, an error, or a failure in the context of reliability can be a risk source. A threat in the context of security, a threat agent, or an adverse action can be a risk source.

name: risk state

definitions.text: current project risk information relating to an individual risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.15

note: The information concerning an individual risk includes the current description, causes, likelihood, consequences, estimation scales, confidence of the estimates, treatment, threshold, and an estimate of when the risk will reach its threshold.

name: risk threshold

definitions.text: measure of the level of uncertainty or the level of impact at which a stakeholder may have a specific interest. Below that risk threshold, the organization will accept the risk. Above that risk threshold, the organization will not tolerate the risk
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: condition that triggers some stakeholder action
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.16

note: Different risk thresholds can be defined for each risk, risk category or combination of risks, based on differing risk criteria.

definitions.text: the degree, amount, or volume of risk that an organization or individual will withstand
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: transferring responsibility for managing a risk factor to another organization or functional entity better able to mitigate the risk factor
a risk response strategy whereby the project team shifts the impact of a threat to a third party, together with ownership of the response
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: risk treatment

definitions.text: process of selection and implementation of measures to modify risk
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.17

definitions.text: means of modifying risk
process to eliminate risk or reduce it to a tolerable level
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15026-3:2015 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software assurance — Part 3: System integrity levels, 3.20

note: Risk treatment measures can include avoiding, optimizing, transferring, or retaining risk.

definitions.text: predetermined threshold value of a risk metric that triggers invocation of a contingency plan when the risk metric crosses the threshold
review and determination of the timing of actions which may need to occur sooner than other risk items
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: testing in which the management, selection, prioritization, and use of testing activities and resources are consciously based on corresponding types and levels of analyzed risk

software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to
example: a nominal scale which corresponds to a set of categories, an ordinal scale which corresponds to an ordered set of scale points, an interval scale which corresponds to an ordered scale with equidistant scale points, and a ratio scale which not only has equidistant scale points but also possesses an absolute zero

example: If an organization needs to know the size of its software portfolio, then the Scope of the FSM will include all the functional user requirements currently utilized. definitions.text: a quantitative risk analysis and modeling technique used to help determine which risks have the most potential impact on the project. It examines the extent to which the uncertainty of each project element affects the objective being examined when all other uncertain elements are held at their baseline values. The typical display of results is in the form of a tornado diagram
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: risk-analysis technique that studies how changes in the values of estimated parameters affects the desirability of an alternative. Parameters where small changes in estimated values cause larger changes in desirability are said to be more sensitive. Sensitivity analysis guides the decision maker in identifying the estimated parameters (the sensitive ones) that deserve more careful study to improve the accuracy of the estimate.

An Application Management organization can be the service provider, but it can also be a customer itself, of another supplier.

name: software asset management (SAM)

definitions.text: control and protection of software and related assets within an organization, and control and protection of information about related assets which are needed in order to control and protect software assets.
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770- 5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.35

note: infrastructure and processes necessary for the effective management, control and protection of the software assets within an organization, throughout all stages of their lifecycle

definitions.text: types of quantifiable properties and relationships whose instances to describe the dynamic behavior of software execution
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.3-2004 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying Software Behavior

name: software characteristic

definitions.text: inherent, possibly accidental, trait, quality, or property of software.

example: functionality, performance, attributes, design constraints, number of states, lines of branches

name: software component (SC)

definitions.text: entity with discrete structure, such as an assembly or software module, within a system considered at a particular level of analysis
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.36

definitions.text: functionally or logically distinct part of a software configuration item, distinguished for the purpose of convenience in designing and specifying a complex SCI as an assembly of subordinate elements
software system or element
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 2.32

example: data, document, module, unit
note: Software component refers to a part of a whole, such as a component of a software product or a component of a software identification tag.

name: software configuration item (SCI)

definitions.text: software entity that has been established as a configuration item

note: The SCI exists where functional allocations have been made that clearly distinguish equipment functions from software functions and where the software has been established as a configurable item.

definitions.text: process of applying configuration management throughout the software life cycle to ensure the completeness and correctness of SCIs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 15846:1998 Information technology — Software life cycle processes — Configuration Management, 4.4

definitions.text: entity that uses an entitlement of a software package
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.37

name: software creator

definitions.text: person or organization that creates a software product or package
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.38

note: This entity might or might not own the rights to sell or distribute the software.

definitions.text: use of scientific principles, technical information, and imagination in the definition of a software system to perform pre-specified functions with maximum economy and efficiency
review of a software product to determine compliance with requirements, standards, and contractual documents
fundamental idea (such as information hiding) that can be applied to designing a system

name: software design description (SDD)

definitions.text: representation of software created to facilitate analysis, planning, implementation, and decision-making
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.28

note: The software design description is used as a medium for communicating software design information and can be thought of as a blueprint or model of the system.

name: software design notation

definitions.text: means of describing a software design

example: structure charts and pseudocode
note: It can be diagrammatic, symbolic, or textual.

definitions.text: evaluation of a design to determine correctness with respect to stated requirements, conformance to design standards, system efficiency, and other criteria

name: software developer

definitions.text: person who creates software

note: Often a software developer works with other developers for a software manufacturer to create commercial applications. A software developer can also often work as an in-house developer of software for use by the software developer's own organization.

name: software development cycle

definitions.text: period of time that begins with the decision to develop a software product and ends when the software is delivered

note: This cycle typically includes a requirements phase, design phase, implementation phase, test phase, and sometimes, installation and checkout phase. The phases listed above can overlap or be performed iteratively, depending upon the software development approach used. This term is sometimes used to mean a longer period of time, either the period that ends when the software is no longer being enhanced by the developer, or the entire software life cycle.

name: software development file (SDF)

definitions.text: collection of material pertinent to the development of a given software unit or set of related units

note: Contents typically include the requirements, design, technical reports, code listings, test plans, test results, problem reports, schedules, and notes for the units.

definitions.text: software library containing computer readable and human readable information relevant to a software development effort
project plan for a software development project

name: software development process

definitions.text: process by which user needs are translated into a software product

note: The process involves translating user needs into software requirements, transforming the software requirements into design, implementing the design in code, testing the code, and sometimes, installing and checking out the software for operational use. These activities can overlap or be performed iteratively.

definitions.text: software development technique in which two or more functionally identical variants of a program are developed from the same specification by different programmers or programming teams with the intent of providing error detection, increased reliability, additional documentation, or reduced probability that programming or compiler errors will influence the end results
system element that is software
systematic application of scientific and technological knowledge, methods, and experience to the design, implementation, testing, and documentation of software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: application of a systematic, disciplined, quantifiable approach to the development, operation, and maintenance of software; that is, the application of engineering to software [ISO/IEC TR 19759:2016, Software Engineering — Guide to the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge (SWEBOK)

name: software engineering environment (SEE)

definitions.text: environment that provides automated system context services and software-specific services for the engineering of software systems and related domains, such as project management and process management
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15940:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software Engineering Environment Services, 2.7

definitions.text: hardware, software, and firmware used to perform a software engineering effort
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

note: It includes the platform, system software, utilities, and CASE tools installed.

name: software entitlement

definitions.text: software license use rights as defined through agreements between a software licensor and a software consumer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.39

note: Effective use rights take into account any contracts and all applicable licenses, including full licenses, upgrade licenses, and maintenance agreements.

definitions.text: process of comparing software entitlements owned with those required (granted and deployed), usually to determine compliance with software license agreements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.30

name: software feature

definitions.text: software characteristic specified or implied by requirements documentation.

example: functionality, performance, attributes, or design constraints

name: software function

definitions.text: implementation of an algorithm in the software with which the end user or the software can perform part or all of a work task
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.14

note: a function does not need to be callable by the end user (e.g., automatic backup or data saving).

definitions.text: software condition that is a prerequisite to an accident
definitions.reference: IEEE 1228-1994 (R2002) IEEE Standard for Software Safety Plans, 3.1.5

definitions.text: information structure containing identification information about a software configuration item, which can be authoritative if provided by a software creator
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.40

definitions.text: set of structured data elements containing authoritative identification information about a software configuration item
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.31

name: software item

definitions.text: aggregation of software, such as a computer program or database, that satisfies an end use function and is designated for specification, qualification testing, interfacing, configuration management, or other purposes
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: source code, object code, control code, control data, or a collection of these items
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.41; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.47

definitions.text: identifiable part of a software product
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1; ISO/IEC 90003:2014 Software engineering — Guidelines for the application of ISO 9001:2008 to computer software, 3.14

example: identification and descriptions of the software product, software life-cycle data, archive and release data, and instructions for building the executable object code

name: software library

definitions.text: controlled collection of software and related documentation designed to aid in software development, use, or maintenance
controlled collection of SCIs to aid in development, operation and maintenance
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 15846:1998 Information technology — Software life cycle processes — Configuration Management, 4.5

note: Types include master library, production library, software development library, software repository, system library.

name: software license

definitions.text: legal rights to use software in accordance with terms and conditions specified by the software licensor
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.41

note: Using a software product can include accessing, copying, distributing, installing and executing the software product, depending on the license's terms and conditions

definitions.text: person or organization granted a license to use a specific software product
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.33

definitions.text: person or organization who owns or holds the rights to issue a software license for a specific software package
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.43

definitions.text: project-specific sequence of activities that is created by mapping the activities of a standard onto a selected software life cycle model (SLCM)
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: software system or software product cycle initiated by a user need or a perceived customer need and terminated by discontinued use of the product or when the software is no longer available for use

name: software maintenance

definitions.text: totality of activities required to provide cost-effective support to a software system
definitions.reference: IEEE 14764-2006 Software Engineering - Software Life Cycle Processes - Maintenance, 3.1

definitions.text: entitlement of additional rights (such as additional functionality, upgrade or support) for a previously granted software entitlement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.1.35

note: Pre-delivery activities include planning for post-delivery operations, supportability, and logistics determination Post-delivery activities include software modification, training, and operating a help desk

definitions.text: software tool that executes concurrently with another program and provides detailed information about the execution of the other program

name: software package

definitions.text: complete and documented set of software supplied for a specific application or function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.44

note: the set of files associated with a specific set of business functionalities that can be installed on a computing device and has a set of specific licensing requirements

definitions.text: entity that packages or bundles software created by others [ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.45] EXAMPLE a value -added reseller who bundles a software package to work with an embedded system, or a software reseller who is licensed to combine a number of different software products into a single bundle
illegal use or copying of software products
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: software product

definitions.text: set of computer programs, procedures, and possibly associated documentation and data
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.42; ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE 4.31; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.48

definitions.text: any of the individual items in (1)
complete set of software designed for delivery to a software consumer or end-user, which can include computer programs, procedures and associated documentation and data.
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.46

definitions.text: set of computer programs, procedures, database- and other data structure descriptions and associated documentation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16350-2015 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Application management, 4.33

note: A software product can be designated for delivery, an integral part of another product, or used in development. Software products vary from large customized application software for one customer to standard software packages that are sold off the shelf to millions of customers.

definitions.text: person or organization that manufactures a software product
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14598-5:1998 Information technology — Software product evaluation — Part 5: Process for evaluators, 4.7

definitions.text: technical operation that consists of producing an assessment of one or more characteristics of a software product according to a specified procedure
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.32

name: software project life cycle (SPLC)

definitions.text: portion of the entire software life cycle applicable to a specific project.

note: It is the sequence of activities created by mapping the activities of IEEE Std 1074 onto a selected software project life cycle model (SPLCM).

definitions.text: framework selected by each using organization on which to map the activities of IEEE Std 1074 to produce the software project life cycle (SPLC).
project-specific description of the process developed by adding the organizational process assets (OPAs) to the software project life cycle (SPLC) and the OPAs.

name: software quality

definitions.text: capability of software product to satisfy stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.33

definitions.text: degree to which a software product satisfies stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.13

definitions.text: degree to which a software product meets established requirements
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

note: Quality depends upon the degree to which the established requirements accurately represent stakeholder needs, wants, and expectations. In SQuaRE standards software quality has the same meaning as software product quality.

name: software quality assurance (SQA)

definitions.text: a set of activities that assess adherence to, and the adequacy of the software processes used to develop and modify software products. SQA also determines the degree to which the desired results from software quality control are being obtained
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: set of activities that define and assess the adequacy of software processes to provide evidence that establishes confidence that the software processes are appropriate for and produce software products of suitable quality for their intended purposes
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

note: A key attribute of SQA is the objectivity of the SQA function with respect to the project. The SQA function can also be organizationally independent of the project; that is, free from technical, managerial, and financial pressures from the project.

name: software quality characteristic

definitions.text: category of software quality attributes that bears on software quality
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.34

note: Software quality characteristics can be refined into multiple levels of sub-characteristics and finally into software quality attributes.

definitions.text: a set of activities that measure, evaluate and report on the quality of software project artifacts throughout the project life cycle
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: systematic examination of the extent to which a software product is capable of satisfying stated and implied needs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.35

definitions.text: coordinated activities to direct and control an organization with regard to software quality
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: function whose inputs are software data and whose output is a single numerical value that can be interpreted as the degree to which software possesses a given attribute that affects its quality
definitions.reference: IEEE 1061-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Software Quality Metrics Methodology, 2.24

definitions.text: requirement that a software quality attribute be present in software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.14

definitions.text: management of the activities surrounding the release of one or more versions of software to one or more customers, including identifying, packaging, and delivering the elements of a product
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

name: software reliability

definitions.text: probability that software will not cause the failure of a system for a specified time under specified conditions

note: The probability is a function of the inputs to and use of the system as well as a function of the existence of faults in the software. The inputs to the system determine whether existing faults, if any, are encountered.

definitions.text: process of optimizing the reliability of software through a program that emphasizes software error prevention, fault detection and removal, and the use of measurements to maximize reliability in light of project constraints such as resources (cost), schedule, and performance
software library providing permanent, archival storage for software and related documentation
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: software capability needed by a user to solve a problem or to achieve an objective2. software capability that must be met or possessed by a system or system component to satisfy a contract, standard, specification, or other formally imposed document
process of studying user needs to arrive at a definition of system, hardware, or software requirements

name: software requirements engineering

definitions.text: science and discipline concerned with analyzing and documenting software requirements
software requirements elicitation, analysis, specification, verification, and management

note: It involves transforming system requirements into a description of software requirements, performance parameters, and a software configuration using an iterative process of definition, analysis, trade-off studies, and prototyping

definitions.text: process of planning and controlling the identification, allocation, and flow-down of requirements from the system level to the module or part level, including interfaces, verification, modifications, and status monitoring
software development life-cycle phase during which the requirements for a software product, such as functional and performance capabilities, are defined, documented, and reviewed

name: software requirements review (SRR)

definitions.text: review of the requirements specified for one or more software configuration items to evaluate their responsiveness to and interpretation of the system requirements and to determine whether they form a satisfactory basis for proceeding into preliminary design of the configuration items
review as in (1) for any software component

note: This review is called software specification review by the US Department of Defense.

definitions.text: documentation of the essential requirements (functions, performance, design constraints, and attributes) of the software and its external interfaces
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.29

definitions.text: structured collection of the requirements (functions, performance, design constraints, and attributes) of the software and its external interfaces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 4.1.24

definitions.text: process of ensuring that the software requirements specification complies with the system requirements, conforms to document standards of the requirements phase, and is an adequate basis for the architectural (preliminary) design phase
freedom from software hazards [IEEE 1228-1994 (R2002) IEEE Standard for Software Safety Plans, 3.1.6] cf.: system safety
systematic approach to reducing software risks
definitions.reference: IEEE 1228-1994 (R2002) IEEE Standard for Software Safety Plans, 3.1.7

definitions.text: system for which software is of primary importance to the stakeholders

name: software test environment (STE)

definitions.text: facilities, hardware, software, firmware, procedures, and documentation needed to perform qualification or other testing of software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.15

note: Elements include simulators, code analyzers, test case generators, path analyzers, and elements used in the software engineering environment

definitions.text: event occurring during the execution of a software test that requires investigation.
activity in which a system or component is executed under specified conditions, the results are observed or recorded, and an evaluation is made of some aspect of the system or component
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: dynamic verification that a program provides expected behaviors on a finite set of test cases, suitably selected from the usually infinite executions domain
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 19759:2016 Software Engineering — Guide to the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge (SWEBOK), 4

definitions.text: facilities, hardware, software, firmware, procedures, and documentation needed to perform testing of software
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes

name: software tool

definitions.text: computer program used in the development, testing, analysis, or maintenance of a program or its documentation
software product providing automatic support for software life-cycle tasks
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 15846:1998 Information technology — Software life cycle processes — Configuration Management, 4.6

example: comparator, cross-reference generator, decompiler, driver, editor, flowcharter, monitor, test case generator, timing analyzer

definitions.text: controlled and coordinated sequence of actions wherein software development passes from the organization performing initial software development to the organization performing software maintenance
definitions.reference: IEEE 14764-2006 Software Engineering - Software Life Cycle Processes - Maintenance, 3.10

definitions.text: atomic-level software component of the software architecture that can be subjected to standalone testin
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.49

definitions.text: separately compilable piece of code
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.43

name: software usage

definitions.text: consumption against a software entitlement measured as defined by the terms and conditions of that entitlement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.47

note: Depending on the specific terms and conditions, usage can include accessing, copying, distributing, installing and executing software.

definitions.text: electronic or printed body of material that provides information to users of software

explicit and immutable version identifier (name or number) inserted into each configuration item, including each individual release, that can be used to identify the exact version of the configuration item in any instance or repository
definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: computer system controlled by software.

name: software-intensive system

definitions.text: system for which software is a major technical challenge and is perhaps the major factor that affects system schedule, cost, and risk
definitions.reference: IEEE 1062-2015 IEEE Recommended Practice for Software Acquisition, 3.1

note: In the most general case, a software-intensive system is comprised of hardware, software, people, and manual procedures.

name: software/system element

definitions.text: element that defines and prescribes what a software or system is composed of
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 18018:2010 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for configuration management tool capabilities, 3.12

example: requirements, design, code, test cases, and version number
note: An element can contain sub elements or other software/system elements that are dependent on the top-level element.

definitions.text: system-of-interest [ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.2
small outline integrated circuit
environment in which a solution or set of solutions resides
statement of objectives
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.1:2014 IEEE Standard for Application of Systems Engineering on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: standard operating procedure
small outline package
system on a programmable chip
symbol representing the name of a set
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.23

definitions.text: activity of sequencing of rows or records in a transactional function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.48

definitions.text: system of systems
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.2

name: source

definitions.text: item or activity having a potential for a consequence
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 16085:2006 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Risk management, 3.18

note: In the context of safety, source is a hazard (refer to ISO/IEC Guide 51:2014).

definitions.text: address of a device or storage location from which data is to be transferred

name: source code

definitions.text: computer instructions and data definitions expressed in a form suitable for input to an assembler, compiler, or other translator

note: A source program is made up of source code

definitions.text: arrangement of source code, including layout of code within a single file and packaging of source code into modules, classes, physical files, and so on

name: source language

definitions.text: language in which the input to a machine-aided translation process is represente

example: the language used to write a computer program

definitions.text: node associated with the start of an arc
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-2:2011 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 2: Transfer format, 4.1.17

definitions.text: computer program that must be compiled, assembled, or otherwise translated in order to be executed by a computer
a set of attributes desired by the buyer which a seller must meet or exceed to be selected for a contract
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: source statements (SS)

definitions.text: encoded logic of the software product

note: Source statements can be classified by function as executable, data declaration, compiler directive, or comment. They can also be classified as deliverable or nondeliverable.

definitions.text: statement of work
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition; ISO/IEC TR 29110-5-6-2:2014 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 5-6-2: Systems engineering — Management and engineering guide: Generic profile group: Basic profile, 4.2

definitions.text: dividing action, where the enabled chains will not join
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.1.6

name: special cause

definitions.text: source of variation that is not inherent in the system, is not predictable, and is intermittent

example: It can be assigned to a defect in the system. On a control chart, it is indicated by points beyond the control limits or non-random patterns within the control limits

definitions.text: register used to control or monitor functions in a microprocessor

name: specialize

definitions.text: change by an instance from being an instance of its current class to being additionally an instance of one (or more) of the subclasses of the current subclass
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.181

note: A specialized instance acquires a different (lower) lowclass.

definitions.text: symbol used when the precise nature or form of, for example, the process or data media is known and when it is necessary to depict the actual medium
definitions.reference: ISO 5807:1985 Information processing — Documentation symbols and conventions for data, program and system flowcharts, program network charts and system resources charts, 3.2

definitions.text: detailed formulation, in document form, which provides a definitive description of a system for the purpose of developing or validating the system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: information item that identifies, in a complete, precise, and verifiable manner, the requirements, design, behavior, or other expected characteristics of a system, service, or process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.24

definitions.text: a document that specifies, in a complete, precise, verifiable manner, the requirements, design, behavior, or other characteristics of a system, component, product, result, or service and, often, the procedures for determining whether these provisions have been satisfied. Examples are: requirement specification, design specification, product specification, and test specification
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: concrete representation of a model in some notation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 7.4

definitions.text: a document used in configuration management to propose, transmit, and record changes to a specification

name: specification language

definitions.text: a language, often a machine-processible combination of natural and formal language, used to express the requirements, design, behavior, or other characteristics of a system or component

example: a design language or requirements specification language

definitions.text: the area, on either side of the centerline, or mean, of data plotted on a control chart that meets the customer's requirements for a product or service. This area may be greater than or less than the area defined by the control limits
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: diagram that depicts the specifications for a given system and shows their relationships to one another.
testing in which the principal test basis is the external inputs and outputs of the test item, commonly based on a specification, rather than its implementation in source code or executable software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.39

definitions.text: schedule performance index
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: serial peripheral interface
system/software process improvement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-3-4:2015 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 3-4: Autonomy-based improvement method, 4.2

definitions.text: model of the software development process in which the constituent activities, typically requirements analysis, preliminary and detailed design, coding, integration, and testing, are performed iteratively until the software is complete
software project life cycle.
software project life cycle model.
software project life cycle process.

name: split key

definitions.text: foreign key containing two or more attributes, where at least one of the attributes is a part of the entity's primary key and at least one of the attributes is not a part of the primary key
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.183

note: [key style]

definitions.text: Software Project Management Planned Information.
a person or group who provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio and is accountable for enabling success
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the entity responsible for providing the project's sponsor and a conduit for project funding or other project resources
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: spool

definitions.text: to read input data, or write output data, to auxiliary or main storage for later processing or output, in order to permit input/output devices to operate concurrently with job execution

note: derived from the acronym SPOOL for Simultaneous Peripheral Output On Line

definitions.text: program that initiates and controls spooling
software product quality measurement reference model
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25020:2007 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Measurement reference model and guide, 5

definitions.text: program that displays a table of cells arranged in rows and columns, in which the change of the contents of one cell can cause recomputation of one or more cells based on user-defined relations among the cells
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: sprint

definitions.text: short time frame, in which a set of software features is developed, leading to a working product that can be demonstrated to stakeholders
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 26515: 2011 Systems and software engineering: Developing user documentation in an agile environment, 4.14

note: In some organizations, a sprint is known as an iteration.

definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.1

definitions.text: Software Quality Assurance
