name: technical complexity adjustment

definitions.text: a factor which attempts to take into account the influence on application size of technical and quality requirements, which can be used to derive the adjusted size
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

note: Note that if this is done, the result is not the functional size.

name: technical complexity adjustment factors

definitions.text: the set of 19 factors that are taken into account in the technical complexity adjustment (TCA)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20968:2002 Software engineering — Mk II Function Point Analysis — Counting Practices Manual, 10

note: Each factor has a degree of influence (DI) between 1 and 5.

definitions.text: person responsible for providing a documentation developer with technical information about a software product or for checking the technical accuracy of drafts of documentation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.49

definitions.text: the deferred cost of work not done at an earlier point in the product life cycle
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: of software quality assurance (SQA), situation in which the SQA effort uses personnel who are not involved in the development of the system or its elements
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: application of technical and administrative resources to plan, organize, and control engineering functions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.58

definitions.text: measure used to assess design progress, compliance to performance requirements, and technical risks for critical performance parameters
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2011 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle processes — Requirements engineering, 6.3.3.1

definitions.text: collection and comparison of technical accomplishments during project execution to the specified level of service, key performance indicators, or planned technical events and accomplishments

name: Technical Report (TR)

definitions.text: document published by ISO or IEC containing collected data of a different kind from that normally published as an International Standard or Technical Specification
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 2.35

example: data obtained from a survey carried out among the national bodies, data on work in other international organizations or data on the "state of the art" in relation to standards of national bodies on a particular subject
note: [ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2]

name: technical requirements

definitions.text: requirements relating to the technology and environment, for the development, maintenance, support and execution of the software

example: programming language, testing tools, operating systems, database technology and user interface technologies

name: technical review

definitions.text: series of systems engineering activities conducted at logical transition points in a system life cycle, by which the progress of a program is assessed relative to its technical requirements using a mutually agreed-upon set of criteri
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.1

definitions.text: systematic evaluation of a software product by a team of qualified personnel that examines the suitability of the software product for its intended use and identifies discrepancies from specifications and standards
definitions.reference: IEEE 1028-2008 IEEE Standard for Software Reviews and Audits, 3.7

note: Technical reviews can also provide recommendations of alternatives and examination of various alternatives.

definitions.text: standard that describes the characteristics of applying accumulated technical or management skills and methods in the creation of a product or performing a service
a defined systematic procedure employed by a human resource to perform an activity to produce a product or result or deliver a service, and that may employ one or more tools
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: methods and skills required to carry out a specific activity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25001:2014 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Planning and management, 4.4

definitions.text: technical or managerial procedure that aids in the evaluation and improvement of the software development process
viewpoint on an ODP system and its environment that focuses on the choice of technology in that system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-3:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Architecture, 4.1.1.5

definitions.text: test and evaluation master plan
definitions.reference: IEEE 15288.2:2014 IEEE Standard for Technical Reviews and Audits on Defense Programs, 3.2

definitions.text: asset with parameters or slots that can be used to construct an instantiated asset
definitions.reference: IEEE 1517-2010 IEEE Standard for Information Technology — System and software life cycle processes — Reuse processes, 3

definitions.text: a partially complete document in a predefined format that provides a defined structure for collecting, organizing, and presenting information and data
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: specification of the common features of a collection of <X>s in sufficient detail that an <X> can be instantiated using it
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.13

definitions.text: of an <X>, the set of all <X>s satisfying an <X> template type
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.23

definitions.text: of an <X>, a predicate defined in a template that holds for all the instantiations of the template and that expresses the requirements the instantiations of the template are intended to fulfill
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.22

definitions.text: task-structuring criterion by which activities that are not sequentially dependent, but are activated by the same event are grouped into a task

name: temporal cohesion

definitions.text: type of cohesion in which the tasks performed by a software module are all required at a particular phase of program execution

example: a module containing all of a program's initialization tasks

definitions.text: expression comprising constants, variables and operators built from a signature and a set of sorted variables
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.24

definitions.text: linguistic construct r to an entity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 7.1

definitions.text: result obtained after the binding of variables in the term, the computation of the results of the associated functions, and any simplifications performed (such as gathering like terms to obtain the symbolic sum representation of a multiset)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.24.2

definitions.text: functional unit in a system or communication network at which data can be entered or retrieved [ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary
part of the hierarchical definition of a syntax that is not further decomposed in the hierarchy
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474- 1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

definitions.text: behavior which breaks down a liaison and repudiates the corresponding contractual context and the corresponding contract
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.2.5

definitions.text: program construct that results in a halt or exit

signal in the implicitly defined signal interface of a client computational object which has the same name and parameters as one of the terminations of an interrogation in the original operation interface
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14752:2000 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Protocol support for computational interactions, 3.3.13

definitions.text: signal in the implicitly defined signal interface of a server computational object which has the same name and parameters as one of the terminations of an interrogation in the original operation interface
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14752:2000 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Protocol support for computational interactions, 3.3.14

definitions.text: activity in which a system or component is executed under specified conditions, the results are observed or recorded, and an evaluation is made of some aspect of the system or component
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4

definitions.text: to conduct an activity as in (1)
set of one or more test cases and procedures.

name: test approach

definitions.text: particular method that will be employed to pick the particular test case values.

note: varies in specificity from very general (e.g., black box or white box) to very specific (e.g., minimum and maximum boundary values)

name: test basis

definitions.text: body of knowledge used as the basis for the design of tests and test cases
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.47

note: The test basis can take the form of documentation, such as a requirements specification, design specification, or module specification, but can also be an undocumented understanding of the required behavior.

definitions.text: environment containing the hardware, instrumentation, simulators, software tools, and other support elements needed to conduct a test

name: test case

definitions.text: set of test inputs, execution conditions, and expected results developed for a particular objective, such as to exercise a particular program path or to verify compliance with a specific requirement
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.3.31

definitions.text: documentation specifying inputs, predicted results, and a set of execution conditions for a test item
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.31

definitions.text: documentation specifying inputs, predicted results, and a set of execution conditions for a test item

set of test case preconditions, inputs (including actions, where applicable), and expected results, developed to drive the execution of a test item to meet test objectives, including correct implementation, error identification, checking quality, and other valued information
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.48

note: A test case is the lowest level of test input (i.e. test cases are not made up of test cases) for the test subprocess for which it is intended

definitions.text: software tool that accepts as input source code, test criteria, specifications, or data structure definitions; uses these inputs to generate test input data; and, sometimes, determines expected results
document specifying inputs, predicted results, and a set of execution conditions for a test item
documentation of a set of one or more test cases
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions

definitions.text: designated grouping of test cases.

test management process for ensuring that useful test assets are made available for later use, test environments are left in a satisfactory condition, and the results of testing are recorded and communicated to relevant stakeholders
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.50

definitions.text: report that summarizes the testing that was performed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.51

definitions.text: testable aspect of a component or system, such as a function, transaction, feature, quality attribute, or structural element identified as a basis for testing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.52

definitions.text: degree, expressed as a percentage, to which specified test coverage items have been exercised by a test case or test cases
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.53

definitions.text: extent to which the test cases test the requirements for the system or software product
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.51

definitions.text: attribute or combination of attributes that is derived from one or more test conditions by using a test design technique that enables the measurement of the thoroughness of the test execution
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.54

definitions.text: criteria that a system or component must meet in order to pass a given test
data created or selected to satisfy the input requirements for executing one or more test cases, which can be defined in the test plan, test case, or test procedure
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-2:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 2: Test processes, 4.34

definitions.text: document describing the status of each test data requirement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.56

name: test design

definitions.text: documentation specifying the details of the test approach for a system, software, or hardware feature or combination of features and identifying the associated tests
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.32

note: commonly includes the organization of the tests into groups

definitions.text: test process for deriving and specifying test cases and test procedures
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.57

definitions.text: document specifying the features to be tested and their corresponding test conditions
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119- 1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.58

definitions.text: activities, concepts, processes, and patterns used to construct a test model that is used to identify test conditions for a test item, derive corresponding test coverage items, and subsequently derive or select test cases
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.59

name: test documentation

definitions.text: documentation describing plans for, or results of, the testing of a system or component
collection of the documentation inherent to the testing activities
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.19

note: Types include test case specification, test incident report, test log, test plan, test procedure, test report.

definitions.text: software module used to invoke a module under test and, often, provide test inputs, control and monitor execution, and report test results
activity of performing one or more testing tasks.

name: test environment

definitions.text: facilities, hardware, software, firmware, procedures, and documentation intended for or used to perform testing of software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.60

note: A test environment could contain multiple environments to accommodate specific test sub-processes, e.g., a unit test environment, a performance test environment.

definitions.text: document that describes the status of each environment requirement
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-2:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 2: Test processes, 4.40

definitions.text: description of the necessary properties of the test environment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.62

definitions.text: dynamic test process for establishing and maintaining a required test environment
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.63

definitions.text: process of running a test on the test item, producing actual results
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.64

definitions.text: document that records details of the execution of one or more test procedures
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.65

definitions.text: dynamic test process for executing test procedures created in the test design and implementation process in the prepared test environment, and recording the results
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.68

definitions.text: scaffolding code written for the purpose of exercising lower level code when the higher-level code that will ultimately exercise it is not yet available
document reporting on any event that occurs during the testing process which requires investigation
dynamic test process for reporting to the relevant stakeholder's issues requiring further action that were identified during the test execution process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.67

name: test item

definitions.text: work product that is an object of testing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.68

example: a system, a software item, a requirements document, a design specification, a user guide

name: test item transmittal report

definitions.text: document identifying test items

note: contains current status and location information

name: test level

definitions.text: separate test effort that has its own documentation and resources
specific instantiation of a test sub-proces
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.69

example: component, component integration, system, and acceptance testing

definitions.text: chronological record of relevant details about the execution of tests
planning, estimating, monitoring, reporting, control and completion of test activities
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-2:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 2: Test processes, 4.49

definitions.text: test process containing the sub-processes that are required for the management of a test project
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.71

definitions.text: representation of a test item that is used during the test case design process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-4:2015 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 4: Test techniques, 4.27

definitions.text: test management process for ensuring that testing is performed in accordance with a test plan and with organizational test specifications
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.72

definitions.text: identified set of software characteristics to be measured under specified conditions by comparing actual behavior with the required behavior
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.20

definitions.text: identified set of software features to be measured under specified conditions by comparing actual behavior with the required behavior
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25062:2006 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability test reports, 4.9

definitions.text: period of time in the software life cycle during which the components of a software product are evaluated and integrated, and the software product is evaluated to determine whether or not requirements have been satisfied2. specific instantiation of test sub-process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-2:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 2: Test processes, 4.52

name: test plan

definitions.text: document that describes the technical and management approach to be followed to test a system or component
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

definitions.text: document describing the scope, approach, resources, and schedule of intended testing activities
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation; ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1; ISO/IEC 25062:2006 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability test reports, 4.1

definitions.text: plan that establishes detailed requirements, criteria, general methodology, responsibilities, and general planning for test and evaluation of a system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: detailed description of test objectives to be achieved and the means and schedule for achieving them, organized to coordinate testing activities for some test item or set of test items
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.75

example: a project test plan (also known as a master test plan) that encompasses all testing activities on the project; further detail of particular test activities can be defined in one or more test sub-process plans (i.e. a system test plan or a performance test plan)
note: It identifies test items, the features to be tested, the testing tasks, who will do each task, and any risks requiring contingency planning. Typical contents identify the items to be tested, tasks to be performed, responsibilities, schedules, and required resources for the testing activity.

definitions.text: test management process used to complete test planning and develop test plans
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29119-1:2013 Software engineering—Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.76

definitions.text: executive-level document that describes the purpose, goals, principles and scope of testing within an organizatio
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-3:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 3: Test documentation, 4.26

definitions.text: conceptual framework that can be applied to the organizational test process, the test management process, or the dynamic test process to facilitate testing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.77

definitions.text: detailed instructions for the setup, execution, and evaluation of results for a given test case
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.34

definitions.text: a document containing a set of associated instructions for testing
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.34

definitions.text: documentation that specifies a sequence of actions for the execution of a test
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.34

definitions.text: sequence of test cases in execution order, associated actions to set up the initial preconditions, and wrap-up activities post execution
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.78

name: test procedure specification

definitions.text: document specifying a sequence of actions for the execution of a test2. document specifying one or more test procedures, which are collections of test cases to be executed for a particular objective
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.79

note: A test procedure specification for an automated test run is usually called a test script.

name: test process

definitions.text: process that provides information on the quality of a software product
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.80

note: often comprised of a number of activities, grouped into one or more test sub-processe

definitions.text: review conducted to evaluate preliminary test results for one or more configuration items; to verify that the test procedures for each configuration item are complete, comply with test plans and descriptions, and satisfy test requirements; and to verify that a project is prepared to proceed to formal testing of the configuration items
review as in (1) for any hardware or software component
attribute of a test, indicating that the same results are produced each time the test is conducted
document that describes the conduct and results of the testing carried out for a system or component
indication of whether or not a specific test case has passed or failed, i.e. if the actual result observed as test item output corresponds to the expected result or if deviations were observed
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.82

definitions.text: test procedure specification for manual or automated testing
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.83

name: test set

definitions.text: set of one or more test cases with a common constraint on their execution
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.84

definitions.text: collection of test cases for the purpose of testing a specific test objective
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-2:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 2: Test processes, 4.62

note: The test sets will typically reflect the feature sets, but they could contain test cases for a number of feature sets. Test cases for a test set could be selected based on the identified risks, test basis, retesting, or regression testing.

definitions.text: nested relationships between sets of test cases that directly reflect the hierarchic decomposition of the test objectives.

name: test specification

definitions.text: complete documentation of the test design, test cases and test procedures for a specific test item
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.85

note: A test specification could be detailed in one document, in a set of documents, or in other ways, for example, in a mixture of documents and database entries.

definitions.text: report that provides information about the status of the testing that is being performed in a specified reporting period
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.86

name: test strategy

definitions.text: part of the Test Plan that describes the approach to testing for a specific test project or test sub-process or su processes
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.87

note: The test strategy usually describes some or all of the following: the test practices used; the test subprocesses to be implemented; the retesting and regression testing to be employed; the test design techniques and corresponding test completion criteria to be used; test data; test environment and testing tool requirements; and expectations for test deliverables.

name: test sub-process

definitions.text: test management and dynamic (and static) test processes used to perform a specific test level (e.g. system testing, acceptance testing) or test type (e.g. usability testing, performance testing) normally within the context of an overall test process for a test project
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.88

note: Depending on the life cycle model used, test sub-processes are also typically called test phases, test levels, test stages or test tasks.

definitions.text: specific version of test target which is used for one-time execution of Dynamic Test Execution or Code Analysi
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 30130:2016 Software engineering — Capabilities of software testing tools

definitions.text: document, spreadsheet, or other automated tool used to identify related items in documentation and software, such as requirements with associated tests [ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.90

name: test type

definitions.text: group of testing activities that are focused on specific quality characteristics
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.91

example: security testing, functional testing, usability testing, performance testing

definitions.text: set of one or more computer program modules together with associated control data (for example, tables), usage procedures, and operating procedures that satisfy the following conditions: (a) All modules are from a single computer program; (b) At least one of the new or changed modules in the set has not completed the unit test; (c) The set of modules together with its associated data and procedures are the sole object of a testing process.
extent to which an objective and feasible test can be designed to determine whether a requirement is met
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.52

definitions.text: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established for a system, product, or component and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.7.5

definitions.text: degree to which a system or component facilitates the establishment of test criteria and the performance of tests to determine whether those criteria have been met
activity in which a system or component is executed under specified conditions, the results are observed or recorded, and an evaluation is made of some aspect of the system or component
process of operating a system or component under specified conditions, observing or recording the results, and making an evaluation of some aspect of the system or component
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.23

definitions.text: set of activities conducted to facilitate discovery or evaluation of properties of one or more test items
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.92

definitions.text: a type of contract that is a hybrid contractual arrangement containing aspects of both cost-reimbursable and fixed-price contracts. Time and material contracts resemble cost-reimbursable type arrangements in that they hav no definitive end, because the full value of the arrangement is not defined at the time of the award. Thus, time and material contracts can grow in contract value as if they were cost-reimbursable-type arrangements. Conversely time and material arrangements can also resemble fixed-price arrangements. For example, the unit rates are preset by the buyer and seller, when both parties agree on the rates for the category of senior engineers

definitions.text: segmenting a project into an early phase that focuses on gathering requirements, addressing major risks, and project planning; and a later phase that completes the project if the outcome of the first phase is favorable.

note: The final decision on whether to do the full project is deferred from the point when the uncertainties are the greatest (the beginning) to a point where the uncertainties are significantly reduced.

name: two-plus-one address instruction

definitions.text: computer instruction that contains three address fields, the third containing the address of the instruction to be executed next

example: an instruction to add the contents of A to the contents of B, then execute the instruction at location C

definitions.text: set
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15909-1:2004 Software and system engineering — High-level Petri nets — Part 1: Concepts, definitions and graphical notation, 2.1.27

definitions.text: of an <X>, a predicate characterizing a collection of <X>s
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 9.9

definitions.text: identifiable entity with an associated predicate (a single-argument mathematical function with a Boolean result) defined over entitie
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19500-1:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group — Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) — Part 1: Interfaces, 5.3.4

definitions.text: universal asynchronous receiver/transmitter
unit development folder
Upper Layers Architecture
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-1:1998 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference model: Overview

definitions.text: Unified Modeling Language
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14769:2001 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Type Repository Function, 4; ISO/IEC 19793:2015 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Use of UML for ODP system specifications, 4

definitions.text: described in terms that only allow a single interpretation, aided, if necessary, by a definition
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15289:2015 Systems and software engineering — Content of life-cycle information products (documentation), 5.26

definitions.text: agreement by everyone in the group on a single course of action
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: behavior that terminates a binding
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 13.5.4

name: unbundle

definitions.text: separation of arrow meanings, expressed by branching arrow segments
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.1-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Functional Modeling Language - Syntax and Semantics for IDEF0, 2.1.108

note: That is, the separation of object types from an object type set.

name: uncertainty

definitions.text: result of not having accurate or sufficient knowledge of a situation
state, even partial, of deficiency of information related to understanding or knowledge of an event, its consequence, or likelihood
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.40

note: often the root cause of a risk factor. In business decision making, uncertainty refers to unquantified variation; the probabilities of the variations cannot be used in the decision analysis.

definitions.text: jump that takes place regardless of execution conditions
exception that occurs when the result of an arithmetic operation is too small a fraction to be represented by the storage location designated to receive it

name: underlying license

definitions.text: license for software use as originally purchased or procured, and which can typically be linked directly to purchase records [ISO/IEC 19770-1:2012 Information technology — Software asset management — Part 1: Processes and tiered assessment of conformance,

note: An underlying license can have conditions associated with it, requiring it to be used in combination with another license or licenses to create an effective full license. It can also have capacity or permission to use future versions of the software, or specify ways or limitations to how it can be upgraded or replaced by a new version, or how the license can be upgraded by combining with another license that is linked directly to another purchase record.

name: understandability

definitions.text: ease with which a system can be comprehended at both the system-organizational and detailed-statement level

note: Understandability has to do with the system's coherence at a more general level than readability does.

definitions.text: graph (sense 2) in which no direction is implied in the internode connections
existence of a single trait or construct underlying a set of measures
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 33003:2015 Information technology — Process assessment — Requirements for process measurement frameworks, 3.15

definitions.text: graphical language for visualizing, specifying, constructing, and documenting an object-oriented softwar intensive system's artifacts

name: uniform resource identifier (URI)

definitions.text: compact sequence of characters that identifies an abstract or physical resource available on the Internet
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.51

note: The syntax used for URIs is defined in IETF RFC 3986.

name: Uniform Resource Locator (URL)

definitions.text: mechanism for identifying resources on the Internet (such as web pages) by specifying the address of the resource and the access protocol used
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 4.25

note: The term as specified by the IETF is uniform resource identifier (URI) of which URL is a subset.

definitions.text: a function that differs in form and/or logical processing from every other function provided by a certain application
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

definitions.text: constraint stating that no two distinct instances of a class agree on the values of all the properties that are named in the uniqueness constraint
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.199

definitions.text: separately testable element specified in the design of a computer software component
logically separable part of a computer program
software component that is not subdivided into other components

distinguishable architectural unit with individual identity, boundary, and behavior that is observable through interactions with other such units [IEEE 1175.4-2008 IEEE Standard for CASE Tool Interconnections - Reference Model for Specifying System Behavior] 3.29]
piece or complex of apparatus serving to perform one particular function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group Architecture-Driven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

definitions.text: software element that is not subdivided into other elements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group Architecture-Driven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

name: unit (of measure)

definitions.text: particular quantity defined and adopted by convention, with which other quantities of the same kind are compared in order to express their magnitude relative to that quantity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25021:2012 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Quality measure elements, 4.18

note: Only quantities expressed in the same units of measurement are directly comparable. Examples of units include the number of faults and the number of failures. Hour and meter are also units of measure. Units of measurement have conventionally assigned names and symbols.

name: unit of measurement

definitions.text: particular quantity defined and adopted by convention, with which other quantities of the same kind are compared in order to express their magnitudes relative to that quantity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.39; ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 2.26

note: Units of measurement have conventionally assigned names and symbols.

definitions.text: documentation that sets forth the functional, interface, performance, and design constraint requirements for the test unit.
testing of individual routines and modules by the developer or an independent tester
test of individual programs or modules in order to ensure that there are no analysis or programming errors
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: test of individual hardware or software units or groups of related units
environment that facilitates unit testing

name: universal asynchronous receiver/transmitter (UART)

definitions.text: electronic unit used for serial communications that translates data between parallel and serial forms

note: The data format and transmission speeds are configurable. Commonly part of a microcontroller.

definitions.text: serial communication interface with two data lines and two power lines between a computer and peripherals
to recover the original form of one or more data items from packed data
dynamic testing in which the tester's actions are not prescribed by written instructions in a test case
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 29119-1:2013 Software and systems engineering — Software testing — Part 1: Concepts and definitions, 4.94

definitions.text: United Nations standard products and services code
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-3:2016, Information technology — IT asset management — Part 3: Entitlement schema, 3.2

definitions.text: change by an instance from being an instance of its current subclass within a cluster to being an instance of none of the subclasses in the cluster
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.200

name: unstratified language

definitions.text: language that can be used as its own metalanguage

example: English, German

definitions.text: single-entry, single-exit loop, in which the loop control is executed after the loop bod
in programming, to state explicitly and in full all of the instructions involved in multiple executions of a loop
Universe of Discourse
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19793:2015 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Use of UML for ODP system specifications, 4

name: up

definitions.text: pertaining to a system or component that is operational and in service

note: Such a system is either busy or idle.

definitions.text: period of time during which a system or component is operational and in service; that is, the sum of busy time and idle time

name: updatable argument

definitions.text: designation given to an operation argument that identifies an instance to which a request can be sent that will change the state of the instance
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004)IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.201

note: An argument not designated as "updatable" means that no requests can be sent that can change the state of the instance identified by the argument.

name: upload

definitions.text: to transfer programs or data from a connected computer to a computer with greater resources
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: typically, from a personal computer to a server

name: upward compatible

definitions.text: pertaining to hardware or software that is compatible with a later or more complex version of itself

example: a program that handles files created by a later version of itself

definitions.text: in software design, a form of demodularization in which a subordinate module is copied inline into the body of a superordinate module
user requirements
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 14143-4:2002 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement — Part 4: Reference model, 4

definitions.text: utilize benchmarking results activity
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29155-2:2013: Systems and software engineering — Information technology project performance benchmarking framework — Part 2: Requirements for benchmarking, 4

definitions.text: uniform resource identifier
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19770-5:2015 Information technology — IT asset management — Part 5: Overview and vocabulary, 3.51

definitions.text: uniform resource locator
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information

name: usability

definitions.text: extent to which a system, product or service can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25064:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: User needs report, 4.16

definitions.text: degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.4

note: Usability can either be specified or measured as a product quality characteristic in terms of its subcharacteristics, or specified or measured directly by measures that are a subset of quality in use.

name: usability defect

definitions.text: product attribute that leads to a mismatch between user intentions or user actions and the system attributes and behavior
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.17

example: additional unnecessary steps not required as part of completing a task, misleading information, insufficient or poor information on the user interface, unexpected system responses, limitations in navigation, inefficient use error recovery mechanisms, physical characteristics of the user interface that are not suitable for the physical characteristics of the user, deviations of product attributes from established criteria

definitions.text: identified usability defect, usability problem, or positive usability-related attribute
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.18

name: usability inspection

definitions.text: evaluation based on the considered judgment of evaluators who examine the usability-related aspects of an interface with respect to specified criteria
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.16

note: Usability inspection is the generic term for several methods, including but not limited to heuristic evaluation, cognitive walkthroughs, standards inspection, pluralistic walkthroughs, and consistency inspections. The inspectors can include usability specialists, developers, end users or other types of professionals. The evaluative criteria can include good practice and/or documented principles, guidelines, requirements or standards. The evaluation can be conducted with or without the help of referenced documents.

definitions.text: typically, a suite of evaluation and observation rooms fitted with video and audio equipment for recording user responses

name: usability objective

definitions.text: stated level of usability expressed in terms of effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use which can be verified
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.15

note: Usability objectives can be stated as user requirements, in which case the level to be achieved is a usability requirement, or they can be stated as desired target levels, depending on their use in design and evaluation.

definitions.text: situation during use resulting in poor effectiveness, efficiency or satisfaction
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.19

definitions.text: test to determine whether an implemented system fulfils its functional purpose as determined by its users
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

name: usability walkthrough

definitions.text: usability evaluation in which one or more evaluators step through a scenario playing the role of a user and identifying usability problems associated with successful completion of the scenario
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.18

note: The evaluators can include usability specialists, developers, end users, or other types of professionals.

definitions.text: primary manner in which the documentation developer expects the document to be used
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.53

definitions.text: universal serial bus

name: use case

definitions.text: in UML, a complete task of a system that provides a measurable result of value for an actor
sequence of tasks that a system can perform, interacting with users of the system and providing a measurable result of value for the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26513:2009 Systems and software engineering — Requirements for testers and reviewers of user documentation, 3.43

definitions.text: description of the behavioral requirements of a system and its interaction with a user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 26515: 2011 Systems and software engineering: Developing user documentation in an agile environment, 4.15

note: More formally, a use case defines a set of use case instances or scenarios.

definitions.text: UML diagram that shows actors, use cases, and their relationships
model that describes a system's functional requirements in terms of use cases

name: use case specification

definitions.text: document that describes a use case

note: A use case specification's fundamental parts are the use case name, brief description, precondition, basic flow, postcondition, and alternate flow.

name: use error

definitions.text: user action or lack of user action while using the interactive system that leads to a different result than that intended by the manufacturer or expected by the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.20

note: Use errors can result from a mismatch between the characteristics of the user, user interface, task, or use environment. Use error includes the inability of the user to complete a task. Users might be aware or unaware that a use error has occurred. A malfunction of an interactive system that causes an unexpected result is not considered a use error. An unexpected physiological response of the patient is not by itself considered a use error.

name: use of IT

definitions.text: planning, design, development, deployment, operation, management, and application of IT to meet the needs of the organization

note: includes both the demand for and the supply of IT services by internal groups, specialist IT units, or external suppliers and utility services (such as those providing software as services)

definitions.text: degree to which a user is satisfied with perceived achievement of pragmatic goals, including the results of use and the consequences of use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.1.3.1

name: user

definitions.text: individual or group that interacts with a system or benefits from a system during its utilization
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.3.16; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.60; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.52

definitions.text: person who interacts with a system, product or service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25064:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: User needs report, 4.17

definitions.text: any person or thing that communicates or interacts with the software at any time
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14143-1:2007 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement; Part 1: Definition of concepts; ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 2.27; ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.50; ISO/IEC 29881:2010 Information technology — Software and systems engineering — FiSMA 1.1 functional size measurement method, 3.9

definitions.text: individual or group that benefits from a system during its utilization
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 15939:2017 Systems and software engineering — Measurement process, 3.40

definitions.text: person who performs one or more tasks with software; a member of a specific audience
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.54

definitions.text: person (or instance) who uses the functions of a CBSS via a terminal (or an equivalent machine-user-interface) by submitting tasks and receiving the computed results
definitions.reference: ISO/IE 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.31

definitions.text: person who derives engineering value through interaction with a CASE tool
definitions.reference: IEEE 1175.2-2006 IEEE Recommended Practice for CASE Tool Interconnection — Characterization of Interconnections, 3.17

definitions.text: individual or organization that uses the system or software to perform a specific function
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.40

definitions.text: individual or group that benefits from a ready to use software product during its utilization
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.26

confer: recipients of the results of operating the system or software; a bank customer who visits a branch
or carries out telephone banking using a call center
note: The user can perform other roles such as acquirer or maintainer. The role of user and the role of operator can be vested, simultaneously or sequentially, in the same individual or organization,

definitions.text: documentation for users of a system, including a system description and procedures for using the system to obtain desired results
information to describe, explain, or instruct how to use software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.55

definitions.text: information that is supplied with the software to help the users in their use of that software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25051:2014 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Requirements for quality of Ready to Use Software Product (RUSP) and instructions for testing, 4.1.26

definitions.text: degree to which a system protects users against making errors
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.4.4

name: user experience

definitions.text: person's perceptions and responses that result from the use or anticipated use of a product, system or service
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.20

note: User experience is a consequence of brand image, presentation, functionality, system performance, interactive behavior, and assistive capabilities of the interactive system; the user's internal and physical state resulting from prior experiences, attitudes, skills and personality; and the context of use.

definitions.text: subset of intended users who are differentiated from other intended users by factors such as age, culture or expertise that are likely to influence usability
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25062:2006 Software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability test reports, 4.7

name: user interaction

definitions.text: exchange of information between a user and an interactive system via the user interface to complete the intended task
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.22

note: User interaction specifications focus on user interactions without considering implementation details.

definitions.text: components of an interactive system (software or hardware) that provide information and controls for the user to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.23

definitions.text: ensemble of software and hardware that allows a user to interact with a computer system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 26514:2008 Systems and software engineering — requirements for designers and developers of user documentation, 4.56

definitions.text: interface that enables information to be passed between a human user and hardware or software components of a computer system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19506:2012 Information technology — Object Management Group Architecture-Driven Modernization (ADM) — Knowledge Discovery Meta-Model (KDM), 4

definitions.text: all components of an interactive system (software or hardware) that provide information and controls for the user to accomplish specific tasks with the interactive system
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25063:2014 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: Context of use description

name: user interface aesthetics

definitions.text: degree to which a user interface enables pleasing and satisfying interaction for the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25010:2011 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — System and software quality models, 4.2.4.5

note: refers to properties of the product or system that increase the pleasure and satisfaction of the user, such as the use of color and the nature of the graphical design

name: user interface element

definitions.text: entity of the user interface that is presented to the user by the software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.24

example: a visual representation or an interaction mechanism for a task object (such as a letter, a sales order, electronic parts, or a wiring diagram) or a system object (such as a printer, hard disk, or network connection); basic objects (such as window title bars, menu items, push buttons, image maps, and editable text fields) or containers (such as windows, grouping boxes, menu bars, menus, groups of mutually exclusive option buttons, and compound images that are made up of several smaller images); messages and action prompts
note: User interface elements can be interactive or not, and either entities relevant to the task or entities of the user interface

definitions.text: task that hides the details of the interface to and interacts sequentially with a human user

name: user manual

definitions.text: document that presents the information necessary to employ a system or component to obtain desired results
document that describes how to use a functional unit, and that can include description of the rights and responsibilities of the user, the owner, and the supplier of the unit
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

note: Typically described are system or component capabilities, limitations, options, permitted inputs, expected outputs, possible error messages, and special instructions. A user manual is distinguished from an operator manual when a distinction is made between those who operate a computer system (mounting tapes, etc.) and those who use the system for its intended purpose.

definitions.text: prerequisite identified as necessary for a user, or a set of users, to achieve an intended outcome, implied or stated within a specific context of use
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25064:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: User needs report, 4.19

definitions.text: set of functional user requirements and non-functional user requirements that the users need the system to fulfil
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29881:2010 Information technology — Software and systems engineering — FiSMA 1.1 functional size measurement method, A.13

definitions.text: set of attributes that are unique to a specific user or user group, such as job function or subscription to a service, used to control the parts of the system or web page that users can access
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 4.26

name: user requirements (UR)

definitions.text: requirements for use that provide the basis for design and evaluation of interactive systems to meet identified user needs
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 25060:2010 Systems and software engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for usability: General framework for usability-related information, 2.21

definitions.text: description of the set of user needs for the software
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14143-1:2007 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement; Part 1: Definition of concepts, 3.12

definitions.text: expression of perceived need from individual or group that benefits from a system during its utilization
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 24766:2009 Information technology — Systems and software engineering — Guide for requirements engineering tool capabilities, 3.10

note: User requirements specify the extent to which user needs and capabilities are to be met when using the system. They are not requirements on the users. User requirements are derived from user needs and capabilities in order to make use of the system in an effective, efficient, safe and satisfying manner. User requirements comprise two subsets: functional user requirements and non-functional user requirements. [ISO 25063:2014] In software-engineering terms, user requirement comprise both "functional" and "non-functional" requirements based on user needs and capabilities

definitions.text: simple narrative illustrating the user goals that a software function will satisfy
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 26515: 2011 Systems and software engineering: Developing user documentation in an agile environment, 4.16

definitions.text: a narrative description of a software requirement, function, feature, or quality attribute, presented as a narrative of desired user interactions with a software system
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: terminal that enables a user to communicate with a computer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: classification of emulated users that is defined by the combination of 1) the relative frequencies of the use of chain types; 2) the preparation times (mean values and their standard deviations)
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 14756:1999 Information technology — Measurement and rating of performance of computer-based software systems, 4.32

name: user view

definitions.text: Functional User Requirements as perceived by the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.52

definitions.text: the application as seen through the eyes of the user
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 24570:2005 Software engineering — NESMA functional size measurement method version 2.1 — Definitions and counting guidelines for the application of Function Point Analysis

note: Developers translate the user view into software to provide a solution.

definitions.text: evaluation that involves representative users performing tasks with the system to enable identification of usability problems or measurements of efficiency, effectiveness, user satisfaction, or other user experiences
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 25066:2016, Systems and software engineering — Systems and software Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Common Industry Format (CIF) for Usability — Evaluation Report, 3.22

definitions.text: pertaining to ease and convenience of use by humans
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

definitions.text: pertaining to a computer system, device, program, or document designed with ease of use as a primary objective
of requirements for processes or data, agreed upon and understood by both the user and the software developer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 20926:2009 Software and systems engineering — Software measurement — IFPUG functional size measurement method 2009, 3.51

definitions.text: Coordinated Universal Time
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 23026:2015 Systems and software engineering — Engineering and management of websites for systems, software, and services information, 5

name: utility

definitions.text: software tool designed to perform some frequently used support function
measure of value within a given value system, often measured on a scale of 0 to 100

example: a program to copy magnetic tapes

definitions.text: in computer performance evaluation, a ratio representing the amount of time a system or component is busy divided by the time it is available
real-time scheduling theorem stating the conditions under which a set of n independent periodic tasks scheduled by the rate-monotonic algorithm will always meet their deadlines
verification and validation.
variance at completion

note: Validation in a system life cycle context is the set of activities ensuring and gaining confidence that a system is able to accomplish its intended use, goals, and objectives. The right system has been built. Validation demonstrates that the system can be used by the users for their specific tasks. "Validated" is used to designate the corresponding status. Multiple validations can be carried out if there are different intended uses.

example: Azimuth, which is required to be between -180° to +180
note: A range constraint only makes sense if there is a linear ordering specified.

see data definition

note: In principle, each variation point has at least one variant.

a measure of a team's productivity rate at which the deliverables are produced, validated, and accepted within a pre-defined interval. Velocity is a capacity planning approach frequently used to forecast future project work.

definitions.text: the rate of current work unit completion, measured as work units completed per fixed time period, such as story points, delivered features, functions, function points, user stories, use cases, or requirements completed in a given time period. Used as a measure of burndown rate or burnup rate

definitions.text: branch for keeping track of versions of imported software

note: Differences between successive versions can then be readily applied to the locally modified import.

name: verb phrase

definitions.text: part of the label of a relationship that names the relationship in a way that a sentence can be formed by combining the first class name, the verb phrase, the cardinality expression, and the second class name or role name
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.206

definitions.text: phrase used to name a relationship, which consists of a verb and words that constitute the object of the phrase
definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.206

example: The statement "each project funds one or more tasks" could be derived from a relationship showing "project" as the first class, "task" as the second class with a "one or more" cardinality, and "funds" as the verb phrase.
note: A verb phrase is ideally stated in active voice.

definitions.text: can be checked for correctness by a person or tool

name: verification

definitions.text: confirmation, through the provision of objective evidence, that specified requirements have been fulfilled
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 12207:2008 Systems and software engineering — Software life cycle processes, 4.55; ISO/IEC 25000:2014 Systems and software Engineering — Systems and software product Quality Requirements and Evaluation (SQuaRE) — Guide to SQuaRE, 4.43; ISO/IEC TS 24748-1:2016 Systems and software engineering — Life cycle management — Part 1: Guide for life cycle management, 2.62; ISO/IEC/IEEE 15288:2015 Systems and software engineering — System life cycle processes, 4.1.54

definitions.text: the evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or system complies with a regulation, requirement, specification, or imposed condition. It is often an internal process
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: process of evaluating a system or component to determine whether the products of a given development phase satisfy the conditions imposed at the start of that phase
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.36

definitions.text: process of providing objective evidence that the system, software, or hardware and its associated products conform to requirements (e.g., for correctness, completeness, consistency, and accuracy) for all life cycle activities during each life cycle process (acquisition, supply, development, operation, and maintenance), satisfy standards, practices, and conventions during life cycle processes, and successfully complete each life cycle activity and satisfy all the criteria for initiating succeeding life cycle activities
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1

note: Verification in a life cycle context is a set of activities that compares a product of the life cycle against the required characteristics for that product. This can include, but is not limited to, specified requirements, design description, and the system itself. The system has been built right. "Verified" is used to designate the corresponding status. Verification of interim work products is essential for proper understanding and assessment of the life cycle phase product(s). A system could be verified to meet the stated requirements, yet be unsuitable for operation by the actual users.

definitions.text: process of determining whether the requirements for a system or component are complete and correct, the products of each development phase fulfill the requirements or conditions imposed by the previous phase, and the final system or component complies with specified requirements
work associated with performing the V&V processes, activities, and tasks
definitions.reference: IEEE 1012-2012 IEEE Standard for System and Software Verification and Validation, 3.1.37

name: verification method

definitions.text: a method that tests an FSM method, and provides objective evidence of the extent to which a particular performance property is exhibited
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 14143-3:2003 Information technology — Software measurement — Functional size measurement — Part 3: Verification of functional size measurement methods, 3.1

note: Verification of an FSM method should produce a result that indicates the extent to which a performance property is exhibited, or whether a performance property is exhibited to a stated extent. For this reason, there is no concept of "pass" or "fail". An FSM method can be considered to be either "verified" or "not verified", for a particular performance property, based on whether or not the appropriate verification has been conducted.

definitions.text: the person or organization that requires the verification to be performed and provides financial or other resources to carry it out

note: Versions often identify revisions of software that provide unique functionality or fixes. A version typically has multiple parts, such as a major version, indicating large changes in functionality or user interface changes, and a minor version, indicating smaller changes in functionality or user interface changes.

note: Typical contents include an inventory of system or component parts, identification of changes incorporated into this version, and installation and operating information unique to the version described.

definitions.reference: IEEE 828-2012 IEEE Standard for Configuration Management in Systems and Software Engineering, 2.1

definitions.text: microinstruction that specifies one of a sequence of operations needed to carry out a machine language instruction

note: Vertical microinstructions are relatively short, 12 to 24 bits, and are called 'vertical' because a sequence of such instruction, normally listed vertically on a page, is required to carry out a single machine language instruction.

definitions.reference: IEEE 1320.2-1998 (R2004) IEEE Standard for Conceptual Modeling Language Syntax and Semantics for IDEF1X97 (IDEFobject), 3.1.207
