definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746-2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 3.2.7

name: viewpoint correspondence

definitions.text: statement that some terms or other linguistic constructs in a specification from one viewpoint are associated with (e.g., describe the same entities as) terms or constructs in a specification from a second viewpoint
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 10746- 2:2009 Information technology — Open Distributed Processing — Reference Model: Foundations, 3.2.8

note: The forms of association that can be expressed will depend on the specification technique used. The terms associated by a correspondence need not necessarily be expressed using a single specification technique. The correspondence can associate a term in one specification technique with a term in some different specification technique. Rather than linking every individual pair of terms, general correspondences can also be expressed between specification techniques themselves. For example, composition operators defined in different specification techniques can be associated, implying correspondences wherever these operators are used to link terms in the respective viewpoints.

note: In the area of safety, the term "violation" is used to refer to a deliberate human contravention of a procedure or rule. A rule or policy can provide behavior to occur upon violation of that or some other rule or policy.

definitions.text: procedural form of help that guides a user through each step of a task through dialog with the user

definitions.text: sequence of bits or characters that is stored, addressed, transmitted, and operated on as a unit within a given computer
element of computer storage that can hold a sequence of bits or characters as in (1)
sequence of bits or characters that has meaning and is considered an entity in some language

a permission and direction, typically written, to begin work on a specific schedule activity or work package or control account. It is a method for sanctioning project work to ensure that the work is done by the identified organization, at the right time, and in the proper sequence.
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a subsystem of the overall project management system. It is a collection of formal documented procedures that defines how project work will be authorized (committed) to ensure that the work is done by the identified organization, at the right time, and in the proper sequence. It includes the steps, documents, tracking system, and defined approval levels needed to issue work authorizations.
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a hierarchical decomposition of the total scope of work to be carried out by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create the required deliverables
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: deliverable-oriented hierarchical decomposition of the work to be executed by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create the required deliverables
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-5-6- 2:2014 Systems and software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 5-6-2: Systems engineering — Management and engineering guide: Generic profile group: Basic profile, 3.12

definitions.text: an entry in the work breakdown structure that can be at any level
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a document that provides detailed deliverable, activity, and scheduling information about each component in the work breakdown structure
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: work effort

definitions.text: labor resources required for the production of a specified output

note: Labor resources are usually expressed as work hours.

definitions.text: the work defined at the lowest level of the work breakdown structure for which cost and duration can be estimated and managed
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the raw observations and measurements identified during activities being performed to carry out the project work
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the performance data collected from various controlling processes, analyzed in context and integrated based on relationships across areas
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: the physical or electronic representation of work performance information compiled in project documents, intended to generate decisions, actions, or awareness
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

name: work product

definitions.text: artifact resulting from the execution of a process
definitions.reference: IEEE 730-2014 IEEE Standard for Software Quality Assurance Processes, 3.2

definitions.text: any artifact produced by a process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15940:2013 Systems and software engineering — Software Engineering Environment Services, 2.5

definitions.text: artifact associated with the execution of a process
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC TR 29110-1:2016 Software engineering — Lifecycle profiles for Very Small Entities (VSEs) — Part 1: Overview, 3.77

example: the project plan, supporting process requirements, design documentation, source code, test plans, meeting minutes, schedules, budgets, and problem reports
note: Some subset of the work products will be baselined and some will form the set of project deliverables.

definitions.text: a project task such as constructing or testing a function point, user story, feature, or requirement
definitions.reference: Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Edition

definitions.text: a response to a threat that has occurred, for which a prior response had not been planned or was not effective
definitions.reference: A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) — Fifth Edition

definitions.text: in software development, a visual representation of work for developers who pull tasks from the task backlog; used for on-demand or resource-bound scheduling [Software Extension to the PMBOK® Guide Fifth Editio

name: working metamodel

definitions.text: definition of the specific meta-objects that can be instantiated in the model section of a CDIF transfer
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 15474-1:2002 Information technology — CDIF framework — Part 1: Overview, 4.2

note: The working metamodel comprises the meta-objects in the CDIF semantic metamodel that are used by the subject areas referenced in the metamodel section of the transfer, and the meta-objects defined as extensions in the metamodel section.

definitions.text: in the paging method of storage allocation, the set of pages that are most likely to be resident in main storage at any given point of a program's execution
that portion of main storage that is assigned to a computer program for temporary storage of data

name: workload

definitions.text: mix of tasks typically run on a given computer system

note: Major characteristics include input/output requirements, amount and kinds of computation, and computer resources required.

definitions.text: model used in computer performance evaluation, depicting resource utilization and performance measures for anticipated or actual workloads in a computer system

name: workstation

definitions.text: functional unit that usually has special purpose computing capabilities and includes user-oriented input units and output units
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 2382:2015, Information technology — Vocabulary

example: a programmable terminal, a nonprogrammable terminal or a standalone microcomputer

definitions.text: to record data in a storage device or on a data medium
data movement that moves a data group lying inside the functional process to persistent storage
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 2.28

name: write (-type)

definitions.text: a data movement type that moves a data group lying inside the functional process to persistent storage
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 19761:2011 Software engineering — COSMIC: a functional size measurement method, 3.26

note: A Write is considered to include certain associated data manipulations necessary to achieve the Write.

definitions.text: person designing or developing user documentation
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC/IEEE 26515: 2011 Systems and software engineering: Developing user documentation in an agile environment, 4.17

name: writing reference

definitions.text: data storage entity or other record, or interface record to another software or system to which data is written in a BFC
definitions.reference: ISO/IEC 29881:2010 Information technology — Software and systems engineering — FiSMA 1.1 functional size measurement method, 3.10

note: The number of writing references is greater than 0 with all BFC types where it is applicable.
